column10: Unreal...

This game is a mess. Plays like a computer science student's end of year project. Bugs galore, questionable design decisions. There are times when I'm just walking around wanting to do something and I think, "Why the heck can't I change that?" And I can't recall the number of times a car caused either a full on jam because of pathing issues, or a ragdoll that sent me flying.

But I recommend this game. Not at full price, wait for a sale of course. It keeps the spirit of Indie games alive and well. It has quirk and charm despite the lack of polish.
Very good game with a lot of playtime potential well worth the money

100% Completion: This game is seriously hard to complete. I don't recommend you try to fully complete it. Just kidding! You should always fully complete games no matter how infuriating, hard, unfair, or even downright stupid they are! This game is a great game to teach someone how to fully complete hard games.

Awesome game that they are still developing and adding fixes for. A mindless and relaxing time waster with lots of checklist objectives and hidden things to discover. It seems like a lame premise, but the game quickly becomes a time management/automation/spinning plates scenario that is extremely addicting. The story only took 12 hours to beat, but after that there's still plenty of upgrading and grinding to do to get the final achievements. Like most "simulator" games, there's a lot of nonsensical glitches, but that's part of the charm IMO.  The free DLC is a nice addition and other DLC's add variety to the game once beaten.

I first found this game on YouTube through an ASMR video and instantly fell in love. I love games like this that let you start with a cruddy business and turn it into a success and customize it to your own liking. This game gives players freedom to roam around an abandoned, run down gas station that you slowly can fix-up and get running again. As you continue to play you unlock more "features" and things to spiff up your gas station. I absolutely love the creative freedom in this game. I am aware there is also an add-on you can buy for a fairly reasonable price that allows for even more creativity! This game hands down is an amazing piece of art and continues to get better with each update and suggested add-ons!!

Or its the gas station as a whole cant be upgraded unless you complete a set of missions that are very easy, except the get tips part - Meaning you have to serve customers that you have hired employees to serve.
Both just to clearly pad the running time to a crappy 15 hours

It could of charged to paint walls and fuck of dennis. More tarmacking. More/separate cleaning areas like the picnic areas for staff. But you hit level 5 and thats it. Here more staff and its done. Theres nothing left to do. except wash cars.... You wana do more buy dlc and maybe get 5 more hours

The game feels really unfinished. Like you're playing an early access game. There are literal tutorials with sample text in there. Drivers getting stuck all the time, cars upside down, wheels still spinning when car is standing still, very little variation in car and character models. I spent most of the game thinking they will fix this, but then I noticed they already have 2 paid DLC's and are working on 3 more (i assume paid) DLC's so I don't think they will fix the wonkyness of it all.

Then there is the degradation in paint that you have spent a long time applying to the wall. Why? There is no need to paint the walls other than to make it look nice for the player. If you want to paint all of your buildings you will be non-stop painting because by the time you are finished you can start over again due to the buildings getting sandblasted by the wind. 

The upgrading feels good and there is quite a bit to do, but things do get tedious kinda quick. I can't help but feel not very immersed if cars constantly roll into the shop with 3 flat tires.

I absolutely adore the gameplay loop of rushing around fueling cars, putting on tyres and serving customers at a cash register like a madman until I can upgrade to get more staff. I love scanning items for them to only fly off randomly if you don't drop them in the right place in the basket. I love living hand to mouth and waiting for that one last customer so I can afford to refill my gas and be broke for the next 30 minutes. I love spending all my money on upgrades and not being able to afford stock for 30 minutes. 

No seriously, I love it. Don't change a damn thing.

I love it. I am a competitive player and I like a challenge. But sometimes I don't want to play at disadvantage against other players. And sometimes I am not in the mood for something grindy. I just want something to have my attention and challenge me just enough to keep my attention. That is this game. I learned that you don't even have to rush through this stuff. You only rush if you want to make more money so the game runs by your pace. I love it. I also like the creativity that went into the design of the game. It gets a little slow when they make you grind to upgrade the station, it feels especially slow when i'm sitting on 10k because I have nothing to buy, but besides that the game is enjoyable and keeps me distracted for hours. Worth the money.

Devs are lyings sacks of shit who prioritize DLC over simple fixes THAT THEY THEMSELVES PROMISED YEARS AGO.

Okay, I'll still be harsh, but it's for a good reason.

There are awesome and there are horrible elements to this game. Let's start with the bad.

You thought Klendathu from Starship Troopers had bugs? Boy have you not seen this coding. Truly amazing. Random crashes, getting stuck on thin air, crashes around specific things, graphical oddities, you name it, it has it. Y'know the themesong of Pokemon? Gotta catch them all!

DLC before fixes. Granted, fixing all the bugs is a comical herculean task, not only because they are numerous, but also because apparently fixing a bug spawns at least two others, and fixing that spawns three others, and it's just this running battle against an ever increasing list of issues. But it just leaves a poor taste to offer DLC when your game has more bugs than your average CDProjekt RED or Bethesda title.

Now, onto the good!

The core gameplay is bloody amazing. SOMEHOW they managed to make running a gas station into an interesting task. There are a lot of minigames that you'll be running, and if you don't like them, you can either hire help to do it for you, or, if you just don't want that part of the gas station period, you can simply close that part and be done with it. Okay, that last part is not entirely true, for upgrading the station you have to do challenges, which includes using every part of the gas station, but you can still order NPCs to do most of your work.

The gas station is divided into sections, each of which can be individually shut down. There are the fuel pumps (and yes, you can close off individual pumps if you just want to slow, but not completely stop fueling while you wait for a resupply), the parking lots (also can be just partially shut down if you wish), the carwash, and the machine shop (with eventually two repair pits, and yes, can also be partially or completely closed). The entire gas station can also be closed. There is also the warehouse, but I'll talk about that in a bit.

The fuel pumps are pretty straightforward. You have to try to match the exact fuel amount the customer requests. More pumps mean more cars getting fuel. You can at any time order a refuel of your fuel reserves. You also get a notification when your fuel is below 50 liters. Typical customers order between 10-20 liters, but below 10 and above 20 do in fact happen occasionally. If you run out of fuel, you cannot refuel cars, obviously.

The parking lots define how many customers your internal shop gets. The shop can have a variety of items, just keep in mind, if you stock food, you want to stock every kind of it, because customers get pissy if they expect a certain item, and can't find it. They only look for items that have their shelves in the shop. You have more shelves than you have space for anyway, so it's not a problem, also if you don't want to sell a particular kind of item (like I don't want to sell tobacco), that's also entirely OK. If you put out any shelves at all that is, because yes, you can in fact not put out any shelves, and only offer the bathrooms. When you run out of ONE product, I suggest shutting down either the entire gas station for resupply.

The carwash is unique in that it can only ever hold one car, so it cannot be partially shut down. It is getting water from the sewers, but it is purified by the pump. The purification process is what limits this station, because occasionally you have to descend into the sewers to clean out the trash accumulating in the pool of water.

The machine shop is where you repair cars. A number of issues can be the problem, tires, scratches, broken mirrors, engine oil, coolant fluid, batteries in need of replacement. The tricky part of this is that you cannot buy more "shelf place" as in you cannot expand the storage of components, and the components in and of themselves are extraordinarily pricy, but also extremely profitable. Well, you can actually expand the storage eventually, as you buy upgrades for the shop, but you cannot buy shelves as you can for the inner shop.

The warehouse is unique in the way that you cannot close it down, nor would you want to, the customers don't go there anyway, the only times stuff happens there is when you order products for the inner or machine shop. Then a lorry arrives eventually, and you need to unload it into the warehouse, then you can load the stuff into your shelves. If you have Dennis enabled, make sure to close the gates, and only have them open in your presence, because that little prick will steal. Not a lot, but still.

There are also events happening, like a sandstorm, which you need to clean up afterwards, because the sand prevents the customers from using the roads in the gas station, or a party bus, which leaves a lot of trash. Because yes, you need to keep the gas station clean, from footprints and trash.



Overall, the game itself is solid, the artistic value is there, BUT, the technical execution is just comically bad to the point where the game is barely functional. WIthout bugs, it would be a sold 10/10, with the bugs, it's like 5/10, with the dev practices it's a 2/10.

My original review of this game was very damning.. so many bugs and annoying little bits....
However, after many updates and bug fixes I can now give this a thumbs up as it is a VERY enjoyable game to play. Trust me when I say it is a BUSY game. So much to do.
You start off with buying a total wreck of a gas station that looks like it's seen one to many disasters and should have been pulled down.
But this is you and you are resilient. It is your mission to turn this wreck of a station into a profitable business.
You have a shop to sell goods like soft drinks, beer, snacks, toys and other bits. A garage fixes customer veichles. A warehouse houses all your stock. Customer toilets keep the punters happy but there are challenges...
One brat of a child will paint grafitti on the walls, sanstorms will make a wonderful mess of your hard work and the party bus (tourist bus).. well lets just say that's something you have to see to beleive.
As I said I gave this a VERY bad review in the beginning but now it undergone a lot of improvements.
I don't think you will be dissapointed if you play this. It really is good and has an excellent tutorial / mission progress so you always know what your doing.
By the way the automatic car wash is a DELIGHT
Never wanted to kill a kid more than in this game. If you want to know, buy it. Its worth it.

After sighing immense relief over finally 100% completing this game I can agree it's something I'd recommend to people who don't mind a bit of repetitive gameplay.
Gas Station Simulator is worth the price, but even a small sale is something to consider it for! I got 43 hours out of the game and while perhaps a good 10-15 hours were dedicated to getting all the achievements I still think you'll get your moneys worth.
I can't say this game is for people who can't handle repeat actions. Once you hit, say, level 6 of your gas station you've really got a constant goal - restock, buy low sell high, keep it clean, steal from cars, etc. After a while it gets tedious and if, like me, you're achievement hunting? Waiting to get to level 10 can really make this consistency a slog. Invest in party nights as fast as possible. 
Still, plenty of fun, oodles of gags and references, and the community and developer are active so it's always updating and providing more content. Invest if you get the chance!

I played this quiet some time ago, and I remember it going pretty smoothly with minor bugs here and there as to be expected in all games.

However, when I picked it up now, it's quiet literally unplayable, Starting the game works fine, so does starting a new game, intro plays like normal and all that.  However, as I wake up the next day, I wake up staring at the sky as my house is all of a sudden missing one side of the roof, I can even jump own to the ground where there is supposed to be a roof blocking me, not only am I missing a roof, but the whole goddamn station has no walls, this fixes itself once I press ESC and return to the game.

None of that makes the game unplayable, however, the things that DO make the game unplayable, is when I pull the electricity lever in the tutorial, literally nothing happens, NOTHING, not even a cutscene plays.

And to make things even worse there was only one out of 5 times I restarted the game to make a new game that let me past that section and gave me the cutscene along with the new quest to answer the phone, which I did, then went to the PC in the station, and there I am again, nothing there, tried saving and restarting, still same thing, progression in this game is blocked by an endless amount of bugs.

Until these things are fixed, this review will stay negative.

Gas Station Simulator offers an immersive and engaging experience centered around the renovation, expansion, and management of a gas station situated along a bustling highway in the heart of a desert. This game brings together freedom of choice, strategic decision-making, and the pressure of running a business, creating a unique and enjoyable simulation experience.

One of the standout features of Gas Station Simulator is the freedom it provides players in shaping and operating their gas station. From choosing the layout and design of the station to deciding on the services offered, players have the autonomy to create a personalized and efficient business. This level of customization adds a layer of creativity to the gameplay, allowing players to experiment with different approaches and strategies.

The game's realistic and detailed graphics contribute to the overall immersive experience. The desert setting, complete with vast landscapes and changing weather conditions, adds a sense of challenge and unpredictability. The attention to detail in the gas station itself, from the pumps to the convenience store, enhances the overall realism and makes the simulation feel authentic.

Gas Station Simulator excels in providing multiple approaches to managing the business and dealing with the challenges that arise. Whether it's optimizing fuel prices, expanding the station's facilities, or addressing customer needs, players can experiment with various strategies to find the most successful business model. The dynamic nature of the game keeps players on their toes, ensuring a constant sense of excitement and accomplishment.

The pressure of running a gas station business is a central theme in the game, adding a strategic element that keeps players engaged. Balancing customer satisfaction, resource management, and financial success requires thoughtful decision-making. This aspect of the game adds a layer of challenge that will appeal to players who enjoy simulation games with a business management focus.

In conclusion, Gas Station Simulator is a highly recommended game for those seeking a captivating and challenging simulation experience. The freedom of choice, detailed graphics, and the pressure of managing a gas station in the desert make it a standout title in the genre. Whether you're a fan of simulation games or just looking for a unique and enjoyable gaming experience, Gas Station Simulator is worth the investment.

[h1] Running The Only Gas Station Within A 100 Miles Of The Nearest Town [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ Realistic Gas Station Simulator 
+ Gas Station Customization 
+ Fun Little Mini-Games Included

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- Denis The Tormentor 
- Unreasonable Amount Of Gas Consumption For Player Vehicles
- Minor Game Crashes

[b] The Aspect Of The Game [/b]
[i] You are a man who is driving past a worn down gas station and decided to sell your car to buy the station. It is now your job to turn an old dead gas station into a thriving business! [/i]

[b] My Two Cent Review [/b]
[i] This game is an excellent time waster and pretty fun and realistic simulator. The story is a little strange but the games strengths are more into running the gas station then story telling. This is not a game you can finish in one sitting but it is a game you come back to every so often to upgrade your gas station little by little. The mini-games while running the gas station are okay but nothing special really that you haven't seen from other games.  [spoiler] One annoyance is a kid called Denis that will go onto your property randomly throwing stink bombs around your lot and actively vandalizing your walls with random crap every so often so instead of calling the police and having the kid arrested you instead through various items from small plastics cups to full blown cinder blocks to "repel" the kid though sadly no matter how many heavy items I throw at the kid he keeps coming back. [/spoiler]  Later into the game the grind of having to do everything dies down once you hire employee's to do the work for you and from there on the game get's easy. [/i]

[b] The Value Of The Game [/b]
[i] This is game I would only buy in a bundle or when on sale. [/i]

[h1] Final Score 76/100 Ranking C Tier  [/h1]
The most strangely quirky game that I've ever played. (In a good way)

Probably the only game I keep going to despite the fact I'm already close to 100%. I'd say this game has struck my personal balance between casual and active right on the mark!
It keeps my adrenaline going so I don't get bored, but it also has enough relaxing elements to keep me from getting stressed.
10/10, not enough games are made like this.

I've put a lot of hours into this game. 

Pros: 
The gameplay is pretty relaxing. 
You begin with manually cleaning cars, and eventually get an automatic car wash. You can toggle manual/automatic if you ever just want to clean cars yourself.
I enjoy putting the gas in the cars.
I bought the Ferris wheel and it is great! I mostly just manage the business and ride the Ferris wheel. 
The reset cars and customers button is a God-send. 
There is some online help if you ever get stuck.

Cons:
The game is so dark! Even buying and placing lots of lights doesn't really light anything up too much. Placing lighting in the apartment does not brighten the place up. I found that painting the walls white helps to see things a bit better.
Some of the minigames are very annoying and frustrating. I don't like the RC cars at all and the ice cream stand is annoying. 
There has got to be a better way to determine what glasses you have on the stands and which ones to place. Visually, it's hard to tell them apart on the stand.
Party DLC: The party decorations cannot be used for the party. You can buy and use the decor for the gas station and your apartment above the warehouse.

Good game, love the management system

Review update:
So I gave it another try, and for the most part it's okay, a bit hectic, working the till is really annoying because if things fall in the basket, customers get pissed off at you that they get free stuff... like, just go away already?

The gameplay is basically just busy work, run over there, run all the way back over there, use the slow as hell digger that overheats instantly to scoop sand away. You can turn off sandstorms, but the sand from the beginning is still there. Very annoying. If the digger wasn't absurdly slow, or there were more drop off points, or you could just turn off that feature entirely, it'd be bearable. But the fact that it's required to progress makes it a major problem.

But my biggest issue is that you cannot skip cutscenes. The games story is awful. Some skinhead thug comes up behind you, asks for money, beats the hell out of you and stomps on your face. You cannot fight back, you cannot skip this, you cannot pause it... I wasn't prepared for this when I bought a game called "Gas station simulator". As someone who has been beat up quite a lot in the past, it brought up a lot of horrible stuff for me.

I will be refunding this game, and this review largely exists to remind me to never ever buy it again. And if you have similar issues to myself, you should avoid this terrible game as well.
In most games where you get beat up, at least there's a decent chance you can fight back, but this was a cutscene. And on a game called "Gas Station Simulator"... Why am I getting beat up for running a gas station? Why is there this terrible story, and owing money and the stress that some loanshark is going to stomp on my face? This is stressful as hell, this game is not a good escape from reality. It's not even a very good gas station simulator.

Normally I'd include a message about wishing the devs all the best... but after that cutscene... I hate this game.

[h1]A Mixed Bag of Fun and Frustration[/h1]

"Gas Station Simulator" is a game that oscillates between being brilliantly engaging and frustratingly flawed. It’s a title that offers a unique blend of management and simulation, but its execution is a mixed experience.

The early stages of the game are its shining moments. Transforming a dilapidated gas station into a thriving business is satisfying and well-paced. This phase of the game captures the essence of building and managing a business, offering a sense of accomplishment as you see your station grow and evolve. However, as the game progresses into mid and late stages, its shortcomings become more apparent.

A key issue with "Gas Station Simulator" is its repetitiveness and lack of depth in certain areas. The scripted nature of car arrivals and the predictability of certain events, like the always flat front right tire in garage repairs, detract from the realism. The cleaning mechanics are oversimplified, reducing the complexity of managing the station.

Another point of contention is the game's mini-games and features that seem disjointed from the core gameplay. For example, the RC track, while a fun addition, becomes irrelevant as the game progresses and demands more of your time in other areas. The balance between these extra features and the main game tasks is off, leading to a disjointed experience.

The game’s mechanics and user interface also need polishing. Movement can feel clunky, and the mouse/keyboard controls and UI can be cumbersome. These issues, along with the game’s bugs and performance problems, interrupt the gameplay experience.

On the positive side, the core gameplay loop is addictive. There's a constant sense of things to do, manage, and organize, which keeps the game engaging. The progression system initially offers a satisfying journey as you upgrade your station and hire employees. The addition of decorations and the transformation of the gas station are visually and strategically rewarding.

However, the game’s endgame is where it falters significantly. The sense of progression halts, and managing the station becomes tedious rather than rewarding. Employee management feels inefficient, and the lack of automation in certain upgrades is a missed opportunity to enhance the gameplay.

In conclusion, "Gas Station Simulator" is a game with great potential that is partially realized. Its early stages are engaging and enjoyable, but the latter part of the game suffers from repetitive gameplay and a lack of depth in management mechanics. For those who enjoy business simulation games, it offers an interesting concept, but be prepared for the mixed experience in terms of quality and gameplay enjoyment. The game is a testament to the fine line between a great idea and its execution in the world of video games.

The visual design of "Gas Station Simulator" is both charming and detailed. The game offers a realistic representation of a gas station environment, from the fuel pumps and convenience store shelves to the assortment of customers and vehicles. The attention to detail extends to the day-night cycle and weather effects, contributing to the immersive experience of running a gas station.

At the heart of the gameplay is the management of every aspect of the gas station business. Players start with a modest establishment and gradually expand by upgrading facilities, hiring staff, and improving services. The economic simulation adds depth, requiring players to carefully set prices, manage inventory, and invest wisely to turn a profit.

The customer interactions in "Gas Station Simulator" are a highlight. Attending to a diverse range of customers, each with their unique needs and preferences, adds a layer of challenge and unpredictability. Whether fueling up, purchasing snacks, or utilizing car wash services, customers react dynamically to the player's decisions, impacting overall satisfaction and revenue.

The game's progression system is satisfying, offering a steady stream of objectives and challenges to keep players engaged. The sense of accomplishment derived from upgrading the gas station, unlocking new features, and attracting a loyal customer base is both motivating and rewarding.

"Gas Station Simulator" also surprises with its creative element. Players can customize and decorate their gas stations, adding a personal touch to the business. The inclusion of a photo mode allows players to capture and share their unique creations, fostering a sense of community and creativity within the player base.

While "Gas Station Simulator" excels in many areas, some players might find that the repetitive nature of certain tasks and the occasional lack of variety in customer interactions impact the long-term appeal of the game. Additionally, certain aspects of the user interface and controls may benefit from further refinement for a smoother gaming experience.

In conclusion, "Gas Station Simulator" is a standout entry in the simulation genre, offering a surprisingly enjoyable and strategic experience in the seemingly mundane world of gas station management. Its detailed visuals, engaging economic simulation, and unexpected creative aspects make it a noteworthy addition to the genre. Whether you're a simulation enthusiast or a player looking for a unique and immersive business management experience, "Gas Station Simulator" fuels a sense of enjoyment and accomplishment that sets it apart in the ever-expanding world of simulation games.

If I was hardcore story line I wouldn't have considered it, but for me I'm much more excited to sink my teeth into the day to do tasks such as serving customers, restocking shelves, figuring out what I need from exciting trades etc.
I never usually play any single player games because I just prefer the camaraderie that comes from multiplayer, but this has been a wonderful game to cosy up and play in the dead of night when my fiance and friends and the rest of the world are sleeping. 

10/10 from me, I can see myself playing for a very long time.

Want to teach yourself or others how mundane and time consuming jobs can be for little monetary return? 
Gas Station Simulator.

Want to know what it's like to to unrealistically borrow money from the mafia with the single click of a button and how quickly they want their money back in 24 mins or else they'll break your knees and take your inventory? 
Gas Station Simulator.

Want to know how much loose change and bills people just leave in the trunk of their car? Apparently everyone does. Want to know how easy it is to break into a car right in front of the owner and have no consequences other then setting off a car alarm and losing a sale? 
Gas Station Simulator

Want to see penis ducks and poop emoji grafitti on the side of your station every 30 minutes and have to repaint your entire gas station's fading paint? 
Gas Station Simulator

Want to clean up muddy footprints, pick up random pieces of fish and banana peels and empty trash cans for hours upon end?
Gas Station Simulator

Drawn to play the most tedious and addictive games with very little fulfillment?
Gas Station Simulator

It's a cool concept, but the tasks are very repetitive and tedious.  You fuel up cars, scan items, and do minor repairs over and over again to get to the next level.   You constantly struggle to keep the gas station clean and stocked.   I've stayed with it 11 hours and haven't hit the last upgrade for the Gas Station yet, but I think I am done now.   With each level the number of times you must preform  each task (fuel, repair, scan customer goods) goes up of course, and it's nearly impossible to keep the shelves and garage stocked.  The warehouse is too small at every level, and when you can hire help - you can't get enough to keep up with everything so the player has to run around performing tasks.   It was interesting enough to see what the next gas station upgrade would get me to keep me going as long as I have, but I'm done now.  Even if I decide to come back and complete the next Gas Station upgrade (level 5) I can't imagine playing this more than once.  So I'm not recommending it because a game should provide entertainment for more than one use.

Gas Station Simulator is a highly addictive and immersive game that brings the mundane task of managing a gas station to life. With stunning graphics and realistic sound effects, it offers a truly immersive experience. As the owner, you'll be responsible for every aspect of running the gas station, from refueling vehicles to managing finances. It's a unique blend of realism and strategy that will keep you hooked for hours.

I cannot explain why this game is so addicting.  It makes no logical sense but I'm telling you, if juggling several real-time game tasks is your thing, this game hits the spot.  

Pros: - It is fun to make money and expand the operation.  
         -I enjoyed the satisfaction of tidying everything up.
         -As I expanded the business, surprising new avenues of play pop up.
          -Just when I started getting a little overwhelmed, I was able to start hiring employees.
            -Most of the mini-games run smoothly.

Cons: - The graffiti kid is just straight up annoying and keeping up with him gets on my nerves
           -PC resource intensive and I have to have a laptop cooler to play this.  
            -The car wash mini-game is super annoying and I just leave it closed and make money some other way.
            -I appreciated the realism of having to keep things clean, but I felt like the walls got dirty too fast to keep them up.

Neither a pro or a con:  The story matches the scenario and you will pop someone's car trunk and rob them as part of it in a lock pick mini-game. (No actual graphic violence.)  If you are a parent, just realize there is some dishonesty built into the story, though I didn't encounter anything that really set me mom-alarm off after the initial run-in with the loan shark debt collector.
The campaign alone is great, and the graphics are pretty good. it can be a bit tedious to finish but if you're really into it's pretty good. my favourite part is the car shop mini game.

An exceptional game for about the first 10 hours, in which you are constantly unlocking new features, improving your gas station, and improving yourself as a worker there. 
Then it becomes a bit repetitive, but at the same time you unlock the ability to recruit workers to do some of the tasks for you
Finally you can have workers do everything and you just have to re-stock, earning money passively but the upgrades are too expensive, so it turns to a kind of IDLE game

I would recommend the game to everyone, just play it until you get bored, which may be in the first 10 hours or the first 20, still a worthy experience

Updating this review.

I had originally gave it a thumbs down, mainly due to frequent crashes.  There were some game play elements that I felt could be improved too.

I got back into this after trying the dreadful Pumping Simulator.  There's no point in trying that game as long as Gas Station Simulator exists.  GSS does everything better, with better graphics and variations.

One serious improvement that I noticed is, inventory is appearing on the stock buy screen. I think I originally requested this in the forums. This is such a quality of life improvement.  

Painting is still tedious. Though it seems like if you don't do it, it doesn't affect your business. There are just so-many-sections and boards to paint.  I just don't think a mini game is needed for this, or at least be quicker.  But when you do do it, it doesn't fade as fast. I have sandstorms off, because I don't ever want to get into the tractor again, if possible.

This game is so strangely satisfying and addictive. It is such a simple game with simple graphics, but also so complex and fun. Certainly worth the price tag, if it goes on sale, don't even think about it, just get it.

Before the jank was... fine. Tolerable. But I've come back after several DLC and now we have several new problems that the devs never seemed to care about. And to make it worse, it's issues that affect the base game. That being the Employee Update. In that they now constantly get stuck on props in the world but don't do their jobs, demanding pay to take up space next to a stairwell or trash bin without doing their jobs, in a game where the DLC is already pushing more airplane busywork that's blocking gas station progression that was previous MUCH easier to achieve. Essentially, they created new issues and have provided no solutions. I cannot refund this game, so you should heed my advice and avoid it.

This game is surprisingly good considering the negative reviews. It's very immersive. At first, especially when you are the mechanic, cashier, stocker, and the fuel person, it can feel overwhelming. The thing is, there's no time limit. You get to them when you get to them and they're happy. 

The microphone in the warehouse is super buggy and will cause your game to crash, but other than that, I haven't experienced any crazy bugs. 

Pro-tip: if it's legal and available, try getting high while playing this game. It's like the most immersive experience ever. I was playing this game while high and, when my partner talked to me, I was very unnerved because I was like, "Oh, I'm not a gas station attendant" lmao. I was there for 3hrs in one position. Definitely recommend while listening to some chill music. It's a vibe.

Pleasant game to play for awhile BUT:  then you discover the hard way that this is a development platform for a list of spin off simulations.  As noted by another reviewer DO NOT get the airstrip DLC until you have completed the basic game.  If you do, your progress on basic gets mucked up beyond explanation.  I theoretically have the "Can Touch This"  (Hammer would be embarrassed) add on, but no indication how to activate it, while the airstrip DLC auto installs and (unfortunately) takes over the Station game.  The Store page for Drago shows many, many spin off simulations but, like so many games now, the basic game seems to be more a beta at best and Steam is mostly a mechanism to raise money to develop more incomplete, glitchy games.  If this game is offered at a deep discount then OK for awhile but DON'T buy the airstrip DLC at any price until you have the station of your dreams cuz it frags basic game.   AND basic game is very glitchy (the highway out front ties up with accidents that are best cleared up with... the BROOM?  Look at some of the screenshots) .  It appears to actually be a proving ground for other projects.  WAAAY TOO MANY games like this around.  Spend your money wisely.

Price is right, but you need some rather specific kind of humor to enjoy the game in the long term

I stopped using controller and the glitches and crashing stopped.  The glitches I understand, but why the crashing?  Anyhow, without any of the paid DLCs - it works fine with mouse and keyboard.

Original Review:

I like this game, but I hate playing it.  It just crashes and glitches far too often for 3 hours of play.  As I understand it, it wasn't always this way.  I was hoping that if I avoided the DLC (reviews are rampant with crashing), I could avoid the instability, but I was wrong.  I can't take it anymore for such a grindy game.  Your time is the entire resource in this game and to lose it over stupidly random things is unacceptable.  I get it.  They auto-save like crazy by default and pin posts in Discussions stating to save often and contact them directly with game crashes.  It would seem that for, or after, 2 years they are well familiar with the problems just not the solutions.

When you play simulation games there is an aspect of busy work that is associated with them and it's all part of the process.
However, This game takes busy work to an extreme and it feels like everything is designed to be an inconvenience. 
-Gas delivery truck is set up on the same road as the cars leaving so those cars get trapped behind it
-cannot order more then 1 delivery at a time and store items and workshop parts cannot be ordered together
-cars will get stuck on the obnoxious sand piles left by dust storms
-Rudy is a clunky nightmare to use and runs out of a fuel super quickly
-customers buy items quicker then you can restock them at times and I feel like I'm playing shelf stocker sim not gas station sim
- profit margins are so tight sometimes that you feel like you aren't going anywhere fast
- people will throw trash on the ground despite having empty cans, and cans fill up after 4 people use them
- even the paint on the store deteriorates over time so if you thought that wouldn't need management too you would be mistaken. 

That's just the gameplay. Graphically and sound design wise the game is kind of a mess too as christmas stuff was on by default despite it being October which is strange even if there is an option to turn it off why was it on by default? as for the sound. However on the dev team decided it was a good idea to both make the fuel truck block the main road and make every stopped car honk over and over and over again needs to not do sound dev design anymore. I had to turn off the horns 5 minutes in because it was just constant. Which sucks because those horns are designed to tell you traffic is blocked. Like if a car gets stuck on a sand pile because they aren't programmed to drive around the piles like a normal person.

In short I wouldn't recommend this game, and that's not even mentioning the issues I've read in other reviews around the DLC for this game.

Fun at first, but quickly becomes tedious as the only way to advance is following the pretty crappy quest line. Ideally, it should depend only on your ability to generate income and reinvest in the business. Instead, the quest line forces you to acquire new upgrades and additions to your station in a specific order that doesn't make a lot of sense. I found myself in a rut where I didn't have enough money to continue running the station because the quest line was focusing all my money on buying aviation fuel for planes that bring in next to no income. Why are there planes in a game called Gas Station Simulator?

Overall, this game feels more like a proof of concept than a finished title.

Hello everyone,
I really like the concept of this game. You run your own gas station and are able to unlock new things later in the game.
There are however a few things that i would like to be in the game.

1. Customising all buildings
Right now you can paint every building but you can only change the structure of the gas station house. I think it would be very cool if that was possible with all buildings.

2. Sandbox/Hardcore mode
I would love for this game to have different game modes. If you just want to relax and design your gas station a sandbox option would be perfect, but on the other hand a version that has lots of challenges would be cool too.

Largely unfinished.

The time spent in this game was grinding. There isn't enough content to recommend this game. The parts of the game they did well, you can tell they abandoned to try something else. Maybe a trash eating gator, that'll really make a good game...

Brief:  I like the game.  At 33.1 hours I reached a point I where I completed all the missions, bought a majority of the upgrades, and started to get bored.  (And, yes, I bought all the DLC as a bundle.  I have completed the DLC stuff also.)

Pro's:
* The method the story unfolds conveniently unlocks more features and stuff to do.
* The over-all theme was well done.
* There is generally no bad choice, making the game very relaxing to play.

Con's:
* CON and warning...  keep many saves files.  There are game bugs that will absolutely not let you continue with the same save file.
* The mini-games get annoying.  I say this about all games with mini-games.  The player should only have to play the same mini-game a couple dozen times, not over and over and over, ad nauseam.
* The game is too short.  Once the story missions are done, the game isn't really open to end-less play.  
* I personally would have preferred more of a manager game.  The overwhelming number of tasks and mini-games, make the game start to become tedious and less enjoyable.  Having more employees and having the employees do more tasks would have been better.  (Yes, I have the Employee DLC.  The Employee DLC still doesn't do enough.)

Summary:
It is a good, slow game.  It is not a great game.

Update: 9/26/23
TLDR: 
Out of the 40 hours I have on record with this game, at least 15 of those were spent trying to get around game-breaking bugs. Over 2 years as a full release, this game still feels like it's in early access with greedy, incompetent developers. Gas Station Simulator is nothing more than a stiff billboard at this point, used to sell more trash games that will never be properly supported. 3/10*

It's been a year and a half since I reviewed this game, and since then I've come back twice to check out new updates. The first was for the Airstrip DLC, which bugged out within the first 20 minutes and I couldn't complete the duct tape tutorial. Plus, the game has shit Steam Deck support, so I was quickly out of patience by then.

The second return was for the recent, long-awaited Employee update. Sure enough another game-breaking bug burrows up and devours any motivation I almost had to play this again. What's hilarious is that there have already been 2 hotfixes for this update, with the 2nd one stating that it fixed the UFO button; yet the UFO button DOESN'T WORK! To put this into context, The UFO Button is a quick-fix-all solution that the devs implemented so players can wipe away all the broken crap that happens in the game over time. It's a nifty little trick that developers can use as a temporary workaround while a game is in early access. Only this game isn't in early access. The developers put this in a fully released game because they are too lazy to actually repair their code in order to prevent the bugs from happening in the first place. It doesn't help that they're already advertising their next paid dlc at the end of the patch notes of this broken update. Also, what happened to the Shady Dealings DLC they announced BEFORE the airstrip one was even announced? Shady indeed...

On top of all that, after 2 whole years the devs still haven't been bothered to bring full controller support to the PC version, even though they've since released it on the Switch. They're obviously milking the success they've had with this game and taking advantage of their player base. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So after playing this game for over 8 hours I feel like I am at a point of giving this game a review! overall for 20 bucks its definitely not that bad. Especially in a world where companies like to charge 60-70 bucks for games that sometimes don't even get this much play time. Its not a bad game but it can be buggy, I have had it crash on me once but thankfully this games auto saves made it so I didn't loose really any progress when it happened. I love the charm the game has but really feel like it lacks a few things and I figured Id give some tips here also for the developers!

In short before I go into those tips I want to say if the game is ever on sale I seriously recommend getting it. Its a solid enough of a purchase now and I am having fun still 8 hours in. I would even argue it is worth it at the 20 dollar price tag. It may not be hundreds of hours of experience but its definitely fun for the 8 hours I have put in so far.

Now for the tips to Developers.
- Firstly the Employees (which I know are still in your updates and hot fixes) could use just a bit more work. I am noticing whenever my employees are checking people out they are getting negative responses a LOT. Maybe there is something to the employee system I am not catching but if I have to take over the register every time a tour bus or something comes in because my employee can't handle the line and is getting a lot of things wrong, then there is a problem. They are on working on the register but it seems they get a lot of negative responses from customers.
- Secondly I am going to suggest a simple Quality of Life change. Let us repair the register so we don't have to constantly clean it please. It was a interesting mechanic at first but it doesn't help the repetitive nature of the register later on. A simple upgrade later down the road in terms of progress could seriously help make this more interesting.
- I have seen a lot of car accidents, firstly thank you for the UFO resetter, its great and full of the same character the rest of this game has. All the same though, your AI for driving cars could use a slight rework and would solve so many of these issues. Something as simple as a check to make sure other cars are not on the same road, and making sure they stop a couple of inches sooner when there is something in their way could solve so many of the road issues. Moving the Gas tank is also something I recommend as it further causes issues with the traffic.
- Give us some more tools to mess with the gas station profits please. I have noticed that a lot of the prices of items and gas fluctuate. Allow me to also set up my own prices and control how much profit I get. This can also even lead to a mini game of updating the sign for the new price of gas if you want to add more to it. You could also add a competitor Gas station across the road or something if you ever get time to add more layers to the gas station itself. This happens a lot in gas stations across the US where you can have multiple gas stations competing for the same customers and would certainly fit the Route 66 vibe.
-Lastly, Route 66 is in the United States, I know we are only one of the like two countries that still use it, but in the US Gas is not measured in liters. We use gallons, so I suggest defaulting to gallons for gas. However Id also suggest having a setting to toggle between the two, it is another small change that makes the game more accessible.

I cannot begin to describe how this game has changed my life. I am a 65 year old retired writer, and there is something about that game that goes deep below the surface level. When you first experience the game, it seems fairly shallow with a bit of gimmicks here and there, and npcs that stare at you blankly, almost like you're living in hell. But if you truly get past the basic functionally and delve into the lore of the game, you realize you aren't running just a gas station, you're running the only business for 200 miles any direction. You are the "buckeys" of this world, with no competition. The jingle of santa flying over is a nod to humanities love and affection for holidays, the ghost is a nod to jonny sins, who is an artist well know for his song "Ring of Fire". What truly tears apart your heart strings is the interaction with your uncle, who at first seems like a philanthropist helping you, but as you delve into it... you realize the truth... the turmoil you've ended up in. You are not casually running a business, you are a slave, an indentured servant, to a man you only get to see once. You will never be top dog, even when you have a fleet of peons below you, you are a pawn in the grand game of chess, you just don't realize it. When you get to the part where your character wakes up out of his oppressive position and the absolute best firefight I've ever had in a video game ensues, you feel truly like you're liberating yourself. When you get cornered, run down into the sewers for your final stand, much like osama bin laden, and grab that SVD, you feel as if the weight of the world is crashing down upon you. In those final moments, where you line up the scope on your uncles head, it's a do or die situation. The man who helped you all this way, should I really pull the trigger? A moral quandary to say the least. When you finally come to, and realize he is full sprint running at your with two golden 1911s, you know he is no longer a friend. He is an enemy. You take the shot, and the game fades to black. While not youtube worthy, if you can allow yourself to imagine a real situation rather than the cheap unity default models, you see nothing less than a masterpiece, an orchestra of betrayal and labor, a tale of a simple man going against his oppressor.  A beautiful much needed story in these trying times in America.

Thank you for reading,

This game is so fun and detailed. You get to design and run your own gas station, along with upgrading and hiring your own employees.

I love how detailed it is. You really have to do the jobs requested, not only click and wait. Eventually you can hire staff to help. Managing everything is nice as the game teaches everything to you in a good rythim, not overwhelming you with too much at once. Relaxing and fun game, a good simulator. It has some glitches and the animations are robotic, but fair for the budget of an indie game. Good job to the team, you made a fantastic game here!

I have played my fair share of these type of sim games. While i did not have the chance to get as deep into this one, i can tell you, its not that great. I wish i could leave a meh rating for this.

The game doesnt have amazing graphics, but im honestly not expecting the best graphics anymore for indie games (its an imposed limitation that hinders style). Regardless, it looks like a game that is brown and grey at first until you fix it up. That is a plus. 

The music is idk, it didn't entice me within the first 10 minutes so i muted it and played my own music.

Now the game play is just kind boring. Imagine you could have car mechanic simulator, house flipper, and some others in one base game? No what if i told you the developers bought the random 99 cent store with sketchy products version and put it in the game. I just wanted to sell people gas and snacks. Now I'm a jiffy lube balancing car repairs, pumping gas (wtf is this new jersey? they can pump and pay themselves), and selling food, while also having to balance all the stock orders and cleaning on top of that. yes you can close for a bit to be able to do stuff like clean and restock, but the time that can take is immense, feeling as if you are closed as long as you are open. 

Also the way you balance you funds in this game is not that great. Car mechanic simulator has a good style that still has some form of punishment. This game felt as if i could circumvent that quite easily. There is not much challenge from decisions, rather it is just stressful doing everything yourself. 

This game is good, not bad. It just wasn't for me. If you like focused sims like house flipper, power wash sim, car mechanic sim, this game won't scratch that itch. If you like mini games with a sim front end on it, then yeah get it! the minigames can be fun, they just feel exactly like minigames.

This would also be a good basis if you eventually want to provide a VR version, which would be great.

Much more worth purchasing then when I last rated it (still has some goofy UNITY bugs that the devs say are "unfixable" - which I half believe, also believe the dev(s) are underexperienced), though there remains some controversy over what should be DLC and what should be base game, but whatever. It's a basically functional game now with a lot of new game modes and features in the base game - pick it up, it's a must have little game for any and all game libraries.

Great game, having a lot of fun playing this.

**SPOILERS**

It's fun, if not a little dry after a bit. I would have liked to see more in terms of designing the look of your store, managing the "official" part of the station (bills, paperwork, maybe a few health inspections), and striving to turn your station into maybe a chain wouldn't go amiss. I would have also liked to decorate, paint, and design my sleeping quarters above the warehouse. Unfortunately, you can't sleep in the bed to progress time or anything like that, so you're always awake and expected to do something-- even if there's nothing to do. The moment you get staff, the game almost goes stagnant; not much to engage in beyond washing a few cars, watching for sandstorms, and refreshing peeling paint-- oh, and also throwing trash at Dennis (throwing garbage bags at a naughty child is a pleasant aside). 

There are cute little nuggets sprinkled across the game. You got a rock n' roll ghost, Santa flies across the sky at the stroke of midnight, and aliens play an integral part in fixing traffic build ups (an excellent, creative "reset" for little issues that happen when you have free range on Ruth and idiotic customers that don't obey common sense traffic laws). The game tries to make up for your lack of things to do by giving you little mini-games such as RC racing and a game that's a mix between mini-golf and shuffle board (I think?), but it all falls a little flat after a while. There's only so many times you can race the same course before you get bored. 

The graphics are a lot better than I expected and your movements are smooth. You can pick trunk locks right in front of your customers (who are sometimes police officers) and they just look at you. Also, if you stand on top of them, you can see the inside of their head. Which is wild. And kind of unsettling. But damn, if the developers don't design a realistic tongue. 

There are a bunch of cogs in the game that make it a good experience, but it ins't really for long-term play once you pay Uncle his last loan. You would open it up if you ever feel like, I don't know, using a cash register or changing the oil in a car, but, so far, I'm not seeing how it can progress beyond that point. 

Still, for the first 10 hours or so, it's fun and reasonably paced. It has updates to the different services offered at your store, and, honestly, it itches a part of my brain that relishes in tedious, day-to-day management.

I have really enjoyed the game. In this game you buy a gas station off route 66 in California. Your goal... make a successful business. As you play you unlock more services for your station that will will earn you more money. You can eventually hire employees to help you run the station. You start off with gas only, and one pump which you can upgrade up to 3 pumps as you go. As you progress, you will have in store merchandise to sell, such as, snacks, drinks, alcohol, tobacco products, toys, ice cream, and more. As you level the station you earn access to other merchandise as I mentioned above, however you start simple with drinks and snacks. You eventually get a car wash, which can be upgraded to a automatic. A car repair shop, which you unlock more repair items as you go. You start with tires, scratch removal, and mirrors. You can unlock, spark plugs, coolant, batteries, and oil. If you get the Airstrip DLC, you gain access to refueling planes, and trading items with them for imported items. Such as maple syrup from Canada, tea from UK and more to sell on your shelves. The game allows you to paint your station and decorate it as you see fit. There is a fair amount of items in my opinion. There are some game features like a kid Dennis who comes and vandalizes your station, and sandstorms which leave sand piles on the station roads that block cars. I found these features more annoying then fun. The options menu does give you the option to turn these off. I played with them on for the start to experience them, but again found more enjoyment in the game turning them off.  Overall, I did enjoy the game. This is one I will come back to as DLC content comes out. Once you beat the story line, you can continue to run the station making money until your heart is content. Though as you do the content becomes stale. It is rinse and repeat in the end. Though like I said, during the progression of the story, and progression of unlocking everything, the game is fun to play.

Gameplay: 4.5/5
The gameplay of Gas Station Simulator revolves around running a gas station, from refueling cars to managing the store's inventory and dealing with customer demands. It successfully captures the intricate details of day-to-day gas station operations, offering a satisfying blend of strategic planning and hands-on tasks. The variety of activities, from pumping gas and washing windshields to stocking shelves and upgrading facilities, keeps the gameplay engaging and diverse.

Graphics and Sound: 4/5
The game's graphics are charming and colorful, creating a visually appealing environment. While the visuals might not be ultra-realistic, they serve the purpose well and enhance the game's overall atmosphere. The sound design, including the hum of the gas pumps and the background music, adds a layer of authenticity to the experience.

Challenges and Progression: 4.5/5
Gas Station Simulator excels in providing a balanced sense of challenge and progression. As you advance, the tasks become more complex, requiring efficient time management and resource allocation. The challenges keep you engaged and motivated, and the feeling of accomplishment when your gas station grows and thrives is incredibly rewarding.

Customization and Upgrades: 4/5
One of the game's highlights is the ability to customize and upgrade your gas station. From expanding the fuel station's capacity to decorating the store, you have the freedom to shape your station according to your vision. The upgrade system feels satisfying, offering a tangible sense of progress as your gas station transforms into a thriving business.

Replayability: 4/5
While the core gameplay loop remains consistent, the random events, customer interactions, and variable goals ensure that each playthrough brings unique challenges. Additionally, the desire to optimize your gas station's efficiency and profitability encourages multiple playthroughs.

Final Verdict: 4.3/5
Gas Station Simulator delivers an enjoyable and immersive simulation experience that appeals to both simulation enthusiasts and casual gamers. Its engaging gameplay, combined with the thrill of managing a business, keeps players entertained and invested. With its mix of challenges, customization options, and a charming atmosphere, Gas Station Simulator fuels hours of fun and strategic thinking.

If you're seeking a simulation game that offers a different perspective on business management, Gas Station Simulator is definitely worth pulling up to the pump for. So, grab your virtual overalls and get ready to embark on a rewarding gas station management journey!

I love this game so much that I've bought it on multiple platforms. An imperfect but very addictive chore simulator with an intentionally bizarre narrative angle. The mini games can feel frustrating and obtuse to start, but I promise if you stick with it you'll get into a very addictive rhythm. Even the Airstrip DLC felt like a bridge too far at first, but once I figured out the rhythm it became one of my favorite parts of the game. I've been playing it for a few weeks and I'm still getting new import cargo items to buy and sell in my shop that I've never seen before, which I find to be super fun. It's still rather buggy 2 years after launch, but I haven't experienced any game breaking bugs. Just some quirky moments adding to the already weird flavor. I will say that once you've maxed out your gas station, there doesn't seem to be much reason to play anymore. There's not much of an endgame event, either. Just some brief text, and then the game just sort of peters out on an endless loop. It leaves me wondering (hoping!) that there might be more DLC. There are parts of the game that seem like they were laying plans to develop further, but never did. Why do you have a living space above the warehouse? There's nothing you can do in it besides decorate it. You can't even sleep in your very gross bed, which would have made a lot of sense since there's no way to elapse the time, and very few people come to your station in the middle of the night. I have read that their upcoming Roadside Diner Simulator somehow connects to your Gas Station Simulator game. I think the diner appears across the street from your gas station? No idea how that will affect either game but super curious to see.

It's pretty fun, but the bugs are completely game-killing. (TLDR at bottom)

- ((half fixed)) Can't repair cars cuz' the tire and mirror minigames get stuck

- ((not fixed)) Sometimes when you've lockpicked a car succesfully, it just resets the lock and you have to try again

- ((fixed)) Now that i've bought some decorations, my cleaning employee is mistaking them for trash and gets stuck trying to clean uncleanable trash. wow. i can't even remove the trash myself, so no way to fix it

- ((fixed)) Not a bug but somehow the ONLY time the party bus shows up is when i'm closed xd 
^ they fixed it by making it so they go into your shop even when your shop is closed,,, which works, but uh... it's an interesting way to do it for sure. (the station is still open though, i had my repair shop running while i was doing other things and suddenly realized there were 7 people waiting at the cash register xD)



((UPDATE)) 
- did as the dev asked, started a new game and instantly crashed, lmao.

- have to keep switching between controller and mouse cuz some of the functions do not work

- trying to rotate a lamp but rotating it (with my controller) makes me put it back in my inventory for some reason

- big fan of the management tab tho, kudos for that ^^

- during calls with uncle, if i try to scroll through the dialogue it will just jump back up so i don't get subtitles on part of the dialogue xd (and it won't scroll at all on my controller)

- tried to play the guitar in the warehouse and crashed

- changing the tire on cars now actually works, tho it's still kinda trash with a controller... and the mirror still gets stuck lol (on controller) ,,,i'd recommend you use mouse+keyboard for everything in the garage so you don't end up having to reload, but the scratch remover wouldn't work for me without my controller, so honestly, idek.

- upgrading your gas station removes roof paint for some reason

- Some NPCs get stuck outside the station while others have no problem getting in, so they take up parking space until i close the station

- the sponge for the cash register game sometimes doesn't want to scrub, so i have to click randomly with my mouse until it decides to work



TLDR: The game sucks if you use a controller, you have to switch between that and mouse (haven't tried unplugging my controller to play with just mouse+keyboard so maybe that'll work for you), it still crashes randomly, and is overall really janky, but it's genuinely a fun game, i just wouldn't recommend it to anyone with less patience than me, lol.

[b]REVISED REVIEW[/b]

Pro's:
- The concept of the game is super fun. Getting to run and upgrade your own gas station is really nice
- There are a lot of mini games that you get to play while doing the basic tasks like pumping gas, fixing cars or scanning groceries
- Some might call it child abuse, but I loved throwing trash bags at Dennis
- There are a lot of different items that you can sell in your shop
- Getting to lock pick your customers cars is fun and a quick and easy way to get some more money. 
- (Revised review) The optimization is A LOT better now than it was before. The loading times are short and the fps drops are minimal. I only experienced "low" fps during the parties. 
- (Revised review) Free DLC has been added to the game which includes a party area and an ice cream station. 
- (Revised review) Since my last review they added a car wash, which I really enjoyed
- (Revised review) Lots of decorative options to spend you hard earned cash on 
- (Revised review) Steam achievements are fully functional now! 
- (Revised review) Gas station simulator scratches the simulator game itch

Con's:
- [strike]The game is extremely poorly optimized (I have a high end gaming pc that's having a rough time with this game) [/strike]
- The game is filled with bugs [strike]and about 50% of them is actually game breaking. I had to reload old save files so many times that I lost count [/strike] not as game breaking as before. Maybe it's also part of the simulator games charm
- [strike]The game crashes every now and then for no specific reason [/strike]
- RUDY
- I don't see any additional value of the minigames behind the gas station
- The employees are too slow at their jobs (even at level 10. If you want to get all achievements you have to do all the tasks manually.
- [strike]Steam achievements are bugged and won't unlock which makes it impossible to even complete the game at 100% (I heard they will patch this in their next patch..) [/strike]
- HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK HONK
- (Revised review) Some of the late game challenges are actually impossible to complete. (for example: helping 40 customers at the cash register within 6 minutes. Most of the customers buy a week worth of groceries (15 to 30 items) which is impossible to scan before the 6 minute timer passes.  
- (Revised review) I personally am not a fan of paid DLC when the base game feels a bit empty (for a lack of better words)

[strike]I can see a lot of potential in this game, but at the moment it isn't there yet. Maybe with a couple more updates the game will actually be functional and playable for longer than a couple of hours. (I wanted to complete it 100% before writing the review, but it's impossible). Taking all the above into consideration I decided to rate the game a 4/10 :c[/strike]

After 2 years and a lot of updates I decided to give the game another try. I am really glad I did. The game has improved A LOT after my last review. Most of the cons I mentioned in my previous review have now been solved. This actually made gas station simulator a lot of fun instead of frustrating. I did complete the game 100% and enjoyed going after those steam achievements. The last 2 popularity levels were a grind and mainly consisted of running between the gas pumps and the cash register. It took about 20 hours for just the final 2 levels and it got very repetitive. I didn't want to give up so I kept pushing through and I am proud to say that I am now the owner of a level 10 gas station. However, I think €20,- is a bit pricey for what the game has to offer. With a price of €20,- this game is competing with top notch games that offer more for the same price. I want to say thank you to the developers for reaching out to me and taking the reviews into consideration and making changes a lot of us wanted to see. Taking all the above into consideration I decided to rate the game a 7/10 <3

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

For about the first few hours of the game, it's actually pretty fun. You slowly upgrade everything about your station and the sense of progression is really there from adding new gas pumps to adding new employees to help manage your workload. However, at a point, that feeling of progression comes to an absolute halt and starts to feel like nothing but tedium. You would think the employees would be more beneficial than being money sinks, that upgrades would feature a bit more automation to them like the car wash, that deliveries would be able to unload without assistance, and everything would give you more time to tackle things at your own pace, but that's not the case. You only slowly turn a profit and keeping employees almost feels useless and you could effectively make better profits by closing a majority of the station. It's just disappointing that once I reached the highest levels for my station, I didn't feel nearly as progressed as I did with the first few levels in my first few hours of play. The game certainly has a nice start to it but man, the progression is terrible, the bugs are still numerous, and I just wish the game did better with it's endgame because this is just not how to do it.

I recently purchased The Gas station simulator for Steam. I am unable to play the game due to the fact that the font size is far too small. There isn't an option to toggle the size and increase it. 

 

I had to stand iincredibly close to the television screen before I was able to read the prompts or information about my Station. I ended up moving my television much closer to my seat, about three feet away. In doing so, I triggered a severe migraine. I was horribly ill with indescribable pain, vision loss, loss of speech, memory loss, confusion, inability to read, write, or type, I was violently throwing up and I became completely unable to even use my phone to call for help. 

 

Though I do take fault in moving my television too close, I wanted to illustrate exactly how much of an issue the small font size is. After scouring online forums such as Reddit and the actual gas station website, I've learned that there are many users reporting the exact same inaccessibility issue for both console and PC versions of the game. My screen is a 65" LCD television, and I have also tried the game on a 70" to no avail.

Tldr: It's a maybe from me. The high price, and semi-broken DLC (Can Touch This) deducts several points in my non-existent system. 


---------------------------------------------------
Story: 
I was not a fan. I don't think simulator games need a campaign as such. I understand that the game needs a tutorial, but the forced handholding was a bit much. One minute I could clean stuff, but now I can't because I have to answer the phone? It was very inconsistent. 

Simulator: 
The game did decently at simulating a gas station. However, as earlier mentioned, it is very inconsistent in what I can clean up and repair. A car wreck right at the back of your fully upgraded gas station is impossible to remove. 
I had also purchased the "Can Touch This" DLC because I wanted extra decorations - Only to find out at least 40% was not able to be placed anywhere on the property (chair, gas bottle lamp, etc). 

Endgame: 
at the end, I only had to stock shelves. Being a stock-boy is not what I would consider owning a successful business, but that's just my opinion - we should have been able to hire someone to manage the warehouse/stocking. 

Atmosphere:
 I also did not enjoy the gimmicky scene - Cars visiting the gas station would frequently flip for no reason, blocking traffic completely. Your only way to solve this, is to hit a reset button that have aliens come flying by and swoop everyone up. Cool the first time, but getting whited by an alien ship because of bad traffic AI is not good gameplay. There is also mini golf, but only one lane, even though multiple lanes are buillt. No guest can use this for your profit though. 

The same applies to the RC cars located in the junk yard - fun the first time, but I bought the game to run a gas station.

The good stuff: 

I loved the fluctuating prices in everything, making you rethink to maybe wait on buying fuel a little later, because it might be cheaper. 

The decorations that worked, were pretty cool. 

I liked the employee system, it was nice working up to a point where I almost had to do nothing.

Some mini-games were applied correctly in my opinion (painting walls, repairing cars, scanning items, for example). 

I also appreciate being able to disable most of the annoyances in settings (Graffiti, sand storm). 
The graphics were great, although demanding for a mid-tier system. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Final conclusion: 

It's very addictive because you are always busy, [b]however, get it on sale, or wait for the developers to fix bugs & expand the game. In my opinion, it is not worth full price + DLC's at the moment.
This game is great and has so much to do that you're never bored! Definitely give it a try!

75 hours and 91 achievements completed. Even though my account says I 100% Destiny 2, one does not simply complete Destiny 2. Gas Station Simulator is the first game I've ACTUALLY completed all achievements for. It was tons of fun and I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes playing simulation games. Remember that your broom is your friend and will help you with those pesky cars that sometimes crash or flip over. lol

It's got some quirks when it comes to collision of items on the belt when ringing out customers. Sometimes you did nothing wrong but an item randomly fly's off the belt or fly's into the basket. So that is incredibly annoying to say the least. There are also some rare occurrences of people getting stuck in the spot they are standing. My recommendation to anyone who has the rare issue here and there. Instead of resetting all the npc's and cars at your gas station sign, which removes anyone who was in your store or other locations spending money. Save the game and re-load first, so you don't potently lose out on making money from them. If that didn't fix the issue, then go ahead and press the reset button. Other than that, I don't recall any major issues that didn't get fixed by re-loading the save. 

One final note, be careful running around with your broom in hand.......you'll find out why if you don't.

I do not care about gas stations at all, but somehow this game made me want to operate the best gas station in california. I cant stop playing it.

There's a hidden mechanic of the game that made me quit. The employees are introduced to the game to help with the work load. They actually become the workload because you have to constantly check on them to make sure they're doing what they need to do, call them back from break, or making sure they aren't glitching causing you to pay for nothing. I absolutely hate the fact they don't come back from break on their own/ doesn't show you when they decide to leave. I quit and uninstalled when I was busy with something else and came back to a huge line of people at checkout, cars honking for gas, and a repair car waiting because they decided to all take a break at the same time and they don't automatically come back. Also the payment. Please I'm begging automatically take payment from our wallet instead if having to go to the pc to pay to switch them from task to task. Makes the game frustrating to play once you get to the employee unlock and dealing with too many micro"games". Also in the future if you implement this allow for payment to be taken out even if it means your wallet goes into negative because taking care of the tiny details is too much for what we have to oversee already. I want to keep playing but I think it's not balanced yet and feels like I wasted a lot of time trying to build this gas station up just for every upgrade/ unlock making the game harder and more stressful. Isn't it supposed to be the opposite? Dont get until they fix the minigames or take out minigames to allow for a fun gaming experience. There's wayyyyyy too much going on on the microscale . This game will laugh at the effort and time you put in. It gets worse as you go and more stressful to the point you might need advil for your headache and restlessness at night.

Overall, its an excellent game. Running a gas station like this is pretty addictive, and its not just the gas station. You will have to manage a garage and a car wash on top of all the ordering and restocking. You can get up to six employees to help around the station. 
 The Party Time and Can Touch This DLC are neat. The Can Touch This DLC gives more upgrades, so your bound to be playing longer to get the cash for them. On top of all that, you need to clean up sand after dust storms and chuck items at a kid who likes to hang around and spray artwork on the walls.

Some bugs/ideas:
 The Jerry can for Rudy takes 0 fuel out of the pump. 
 Sometimes when picking up some items in the garage they will go to the mouse like the other times, but then fall down to the floor, teleporting back to the mouse every now and then only to fall back down.
 I doubt many people even care, but maybe a few animation cleanups? (Getting in/out of the car, people taking out the trash, etc.)
 Having people work in the garage for you is way OP, they finish repairing a care in about five seconds when it would take you about a minute. Maybe have them stay working on the car for x amount of time for a certain repair??

I rate this game a 9/10, great work!
