If you've enjoyed JOB and House Flipper, then you'll enjoy this game.   This is a great game for us workaholics. As the name implies, you take over an abbandoned gas station, but as you upgrade it, you gain more option, like a mechanics garage that you work on cars with, a quicky-mart that you have to stock and keep the customers happy.  Then general maintenance of the place in engauging. Even the pumping gas part is done through mini-games.  There's enough going on here you need to set an alarm or get sucked in. My only request is that the developers find a way to have a Steam Friends invite multi-player option. Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Gas Station Simulator offers an unexpectedly engaging and immersive experience by transforming the mundane task of running a gas station into a surprisingly addictive gameplay loop. Developed for PC by a small indie studio, this simulation game manages to captivate players with its attention to detail and satisfying mechanics.

From the moment you step into the shoes of a gas station owner, Gas Station Simulator throws you into a world that goes far beyond simply pumping gas and collecting payments. You'll find yourself responsible for every aspect of the business, from managing inventory, fixing broken fuel pumps, hiring staff, and even engaging with customers.

One of the game's strongest points is its realistic representation of the day-to-day challenges faced by gas station owners. Whether it's dealing with disgruntled customers, restocking shelves, or cleaning up spills, the tasks may seem monotonous at first, but as you delve deeper, you'll discover a surprising level of depth and complexity.

The attention to detail in Gas Station Simulator is commendable. The graphics, while not the most cutting-edge, provide a charming and vibrant atmosphere. The gas station itself is intricately designed, with various areas to explore and upgrade. The sound design adds another layer of immersion, with ambient noises and realistic customer interactions enhancing the overall experience.

One of the most satisfying aspects of the game is the sense of progression and growth. As you efficiently manage your gas station, you'll earn money, allowing you to expand and improve your establishment. Upgrading your fuel pumps, adding new services, and customizing the appearance of your station provide a tangible sense of accomplishment and motivation to keep pushing forward.

However, Gas Station Simulator does have a few areas that could use improvement. The user interface, while functional, could be more intuitive, especially when it comes to managing inventory and employee schedules. Some players may also find the initial learning curve a bit steep, as there are numerous mechanics and systems to master.

Despite these minor drawbacks, Gas Station Simulator delivers an enjoyable and surprisingly addictive experience. The blend of realistic simulation, satisfying gameplay mechanics, and a well-crafted progression system make it an engaging and unique addition to the simulation genre.

If you're someone who enjoys games that challenge you to manage and build from the ground up, Gas Station Simulator is a worthwhile choice. It offers a refreshing change of pace from the usual gaming experiences, immersing you in the seemingly ordinary yet captivating world of running a gas station. Prepare to be surprised and delighted as you transform your humble establishment into a thriving business empire.

It's really hard for me to give a thumbs down, but I wouldn't be honest if I didn't. I can see how the game is addictive and involved and therefore fun enough to make hours pass by like minutes. So 10/10 for content and game mechanics. I do however have to take that all away because of the constant crashing which happens every 20 minutes to an hour if you're lucky. I think there is some severe memory leaks happening here because you see the FPS go down, then a two second freeze just before you get thrown back into your desktop. I could put up with a few minor bugs and glitches, but because this game wasn't sold to me as early access I have to condemn it accordingly. This isn't a polished finished game and you can see by the hours that I've put into it that I have tried to persevere to the end. I'm nearly there with one level to go and finding it now just unplayable. FPS is struggling because this isn't optimised whatsoever. I often wonder if the developers actually bother to play the game all the way to end before releasing it? Do they care? Sorry, but if a buy a car that looks and sounds the business I'm going to be really pissed off if the wheels falls off or the engine ceases 100 yards up from the showroom.  My advice if you read this is leave the game on the shelf for about six months and check what updates have been done. Don't read too much in the positive reviews which seem to be written by players who haven't put the hours in or reached levels where the trouble actually begins with the crashes and crap performance.

EDIT: After several months the developer has responded suggesting that performance has improved. I have reinstalled and even bought the current DLC's which also have glitch/crash problems. I have played to the end of the campaign story with only the final landmarks to install and to get remaining  achievements. There are still times this does crash and there are still some glitches e.g. don't put a dream catcher over the doorway as Dennis cannot run through them. As for performance it runs great, but the problem is I have a new rig with an RTX 4080 and all the other bells and whistles so for judging FPS performance I am now not qualified to do so. As for giving this a thumbs up I'll think about it, but I feel strongly that a game that has issues on release should be under early access.

Talk about a game that's way better than it should be.  I picked up GSS assuming it would be a delightful jank-fest I could play for a half dozen hours and move on.  What I got was a fairly janky but surprisingly competent mini-game-based, story-driven management game.  The game is mostly just a series of small tasks, ring up goods, pump gas, etc... played through simple mini-games.  What the game does shockingly well is pacing and escalation: while some mini-games remain fairly static, adding new parts and facilities adds complexity over time to the point that hiring your first employee hits that perfect sweet spot: you check off *one* thing you don't want to do, or can even have *something* running while you do non-business related tasks.  It shows an excellent grasp of why this loop is so engaging and provides something devoutly desired: freedom from a task, while also adding it's own extra layer of management.

So yeah, I was genuinely surprised.  It's not just a fun little janky time waster, it's actually a pretty well-designed game in its own right and manages the rare feat of escaping the "simulator" brand of "core gameplay loop ... we didn't know how to expand from there."  If you like these styles of games, this is definitely one of the best I've played, ranking well above Hardspace, PCBS and Power Wash Simulator for it's much stronger story and gameplay.

It was a hard choice to say I don't recommend the game, this is one of those games that really depends on you. If you really want to play a game like this, you will get a lot of enjoyment out of it, but if you're just curious, this game doesn't have the quality it should have for a released title. It feels early access.

There is a lot to do in the game, but often too much. Progression is slow, you balance ordering various stock, fuel etc, unloading deliveries, fueling vehicles, scanning goods at the checkout, sweeping and painting and emptying bins, and repairing cars for much of the game. There is very little profit, so it is a hard grind of running around to tend to various people. One of the best things this game should have, is both higher profits on selling goods (doesnt have to be realistic prices guys!), and the ability to close portions of the Gas Station. A lot of the time I had no money to pay into the expensive garage goods, so I wish I could have closed it instead of having people constantly arrive, get annoyed, affect my score and leave.

I dont mind the kid graffiting, its a funny bit that can be toggled off, but please change it so we just click on him once to stop him. Throwing things is a nightmare and he moves quickly.

The game is very buggy. Picked up items often go into the floor, or will still have their gravity so you have to drag them around. Lots of animation glitches with people sat like theyre in cars when leaving the shop. I had a car crash that meant I reset the cars with 2 deliveries, it then spawned 4 delivery lorries after the reset, with 2 being empty.

As other people have said, the performance is quite poor. Whilst my laptop didnt crash, it did overheat, which it doesnt do with any AAA game, it also gitters like mad sometimes.

I wish there were less painful tasks to do, and it was more fun. If employees were easier to manage, like having a scheduel of when they work and have a break so you can rotate employees or close sections of the gas station. No climbing into sewers to empty it often. The price of everything reduced, especially the early garage items and fuel. The devs really needed to get some people to sit down with the game, write everything that doesnt feel good, is boring, and bugs... and iron it all out.

Right now this is not a finished product, and sadly isn't worth the full price either. I really hope the devs will listen to advice though and improve the game's progression and performance. The game looks nice and has a great sense of humour.

Update: 17/06/2023 and there's a lot of jankiness still. There's a lot more things that need to be fixed than performance and crashes, whilst I didnt experience issues with them, the balance means the game is an endless slog of boring and repetitive tasks.

Initial review:

Kind of wish I waited to buy this game either on sale or after they fixed their bugs. I feel like I'm still playing a beta for a full release price. $17 USD is quite steep for all the crashes I've experienced. I lost 3 hours of progress because the autosave feature didn't work and my game just randomly crashed. It's quite a relaxing game, but it's currently floor sweeper simulator more than anything. Employees are just stupid and need to be told what to do at all times otherwise they just stand around and take up my revenue. The amount of bugs I experienced was quite a bit. Let's list them off:

-Traffic build up in parking lot for no reason. NPCs would refuse to move forward causing a massive traffic jam and constant honking. I had to turn off the SFX in my game to mute the honking. Turns out the current way to fix this issue is to wipe the population off your lot by closing the shop. 
-Constant crashes 7 hours into the game. I was spam saving every 3 minutes out of fear I'd lose progress like that one time I was playing for 3 hours only for the game to crash and the auto-save feature to have suddenly stopped working.
-Autosave feature stopped working 7 hours into the game. I have to manually save now despite reaching checkpoints in my storyline.
-NPCs driving invisible cars into my shop and creating traffic in my store while also clipping through walls.
-Lock picking cars that are in your workshop doesn't work. It shows I am able to do it, but the minigame for lockpicking the car doesn't pop up. Not sure if that was supposed to be that way, but I'm guessing that it was not intended to be that way.
-Can't upgrade my gas station anymore. Won't give me the option to upgrade anything but the parking lot. Whenever I click the arrow to upgrade the toilet, gas pumps, or other things the bottom just says "Parking" without the option to actually buy/upgrade anything. 
-As of 09/19/21 (after an apparent update) my game no longer opens. I will get stuck in the loading screen for several minutes and it freezes up my windows. I can't alt+f4 the game. No but barely -  I've enjoyed myself some, but there's a lot of elements that range from annoying to wtf.

For starters, the painting.  Seriously - I'm on day 15 and I've had to repaint the interior of my store twice already.  (The exterior gets painted more regularly on account of the child vandal who draws dicks on everything.  The painting is anti-fun.  It takes 15-20 minutes to fully paint the station and it starts deteriorating in another 20-30 mins after that it seems.  I'd like to paint the garage and the warehouse, but by the time I get done with all that I'd have to start over 

Things get way too dirty way too fast.  I can't go through an order of 10 items in the store without having to clean the belt twice.

Speaking of the belt and the convenience store, the physics is *way* off.  Like, I'll pick up an item to scan and the item behind it will sometimes go flying and I'll be penalized for that.  Working in the convenience store portion of the game is anti-fun, and is one of the jobs I 100% have an employee working whenever possible.

Employee AI is a bit off, especially if you have someone assigned to clean the store.  More often than not I find my janitor wondering around stuck against the door to the warehouse far away from his assigned duties.

Also, and I realize this is nitpicky, but the game doesn't really have a setting.  The distributor you order things from says it's in Arizona.  I just hired someone whose bio says they just moved to Texas.  To add to the confusion, the California Highway Patrol stops by all the time (seriously...to have so many cops crawling around it seems like I should have been caught breaking into my customers' trunks or maybe caught that little brat that keeps spray painting dicks on everything).  It's like, pick one, man.

The thing I enjoy most in the game is picking up the garbage.  I don't throw it in the dumpster, though - I just walk out the front door and pretty much launch the trash bag into orbit like I'm Invincible from the Amazon show or graphic novel.

EDIT: Lets talk about the Airstrip DLC

First and foremost, it's bad.

I'm not sure who designed or playtested this but it feels like they played it to make sure it worked and didn't do much more to play the DLC to see if it was fun. 

I've completed the DLC to completion, i've upgraded everything. Here's my thoughts;

1. What's the point? Trading with these pilots makes sense early on when you need blueprints to upgrade the airport. But once the airport is fully upgrade there is no reason to trade with these planes, and apparently you can't just turn these planes away whenever. You need a skill, some upgrades let you turn them away more often but who cares? When i ignore these planes it only effects how likely they are to accept a worse trade, but for what? I don't want they're trading, like ever. It's an arbitrary system that does nothing for me and doesn't make any sense

2. Upgrading the airport looks nice, that's about it. I didn't see any benefit to upgrading the airport because I simply see no reason to interact with the trading system.

3. The old guy in the airplane is SO MUCH WORK for what...blueprints? I already get enough blueprints why do i need to rescue this idiot every time he visits. Not to mention the vehicle mechanics are the dumbest thing i've ever seen. Who has ever driven a tow truck that overheats when it goes more than 10 miles an hour? 

This dev just gets worse and worse, with all these DLC's and games they are trying to make they're forgetting one big thing. These games need to be fun.

Original game is still fine, but my review will turn negative until this dev learns to start stretching themselves so thin. It's a real shame.

Positives!
1. This game is perfectly balanced, it's fun and rewarding when you plan ahead and consider ROI (return on investment).
2. The story is fun and light, not too seriously but gets slightly stressful (in a fun way) in the sewer
3. this game is quirky and you can tell the devs had a fun time making this game
4. Everything has an animation (I.E. when you reset all cars and customers there's this whole animation and even that happens).

The bad
1. This game will crash, you wont lose much time but it's slightly frustrating.
2. The random events are not rewarding (except the party bus [Which drops FPS]), if the random events were rewarding I would keep them on. As of now they are just annoyances I keep off. (positive is that you can switch them off)
3. This game is not a BETA (early release) and there are game breaking bugs.

Suggestions?
1. Allow a setting to choose how often auto-save occurs
2. increase the range for customer and vehicle reset so that ALL vehicles get reset.

I'd still give this game 5 stars, I had SO MUCH FUN playing this game. I would 10/10 times recommend it to anyone who likes Simulator games. This is an A tier Sim game.

(Edit at 40+ Hours)
This game has gotten some really awesome updates to continue the grind. Main points?

Still recommend?: Heck Yes
Still crashing?: Heck yes
Party bus now drops me to around 20 FPS on a overclocked GeForce 3070 [Intel I9 3700K (not overclocked)], so much so that I had to turn off the very helpful random event.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:


Over 50 hours in this game but only about 10 hours worth of enjoyment in between all the game breaking bugs that never seem to get fixed. The main problem isn't the game itself but rather the dev team behind it. They are inexperienced, don't communicate well and they don't seem to know how to fix the bugs that they have claimed to have already fixed at least once. They even included a Reset Button in the game itself that your character can press if the AI gets itself all wrapped up in the environment, which it will. There's even an achievement for being launched into the air as if they couldn't figure out how to fix the physics so they just went with it. While it sounds funny it's not when it constantly happens to you while you're just trying to enjoy the game.

If you're willing to tolerate a ton of bugs, poor performance and two-bit developers then this is your game. I however can't recommend the game in it's current state. This is not an EA game. It was fully released 9 months ago and they still haven't fixed issues that have been present since day one even though they have already released a paid-for DLC with another in the pipeline. IMHO these are the types of games that you should avoid in order to send a message to developers that continue to think that it's ok to release buggy messes then proceed to ignore their community.

While I enjoyed some of the game play I would return this game in a heartbeat therefore I can't in good conscious recommend this to anyone. Instead, check out something like King of Retail or even Drug Dealer Simulator.

What gets my brain in a knot is the setting and era. 
So in what era is the game setting?
My guess is sometime after 2004, since there is a glimpse of a 2004 Harley-Davidson Softail.
But where is this gas station?
According to a fan wiki, it is set in the middle of the desert between Nevada and California. But here's the rub; there are a slew of Fiat 126's in the game, but this car was never introduced in the USA. Icing on the cake: the Fiat 126 is actually banned from driving on the road in the USA for being unsafe. So for my brain to be more immersed, I set it in Cuba since in Cuba has a lot of old classics still driving on the road...plus the Fiat 126. But there's another rub; Cuba has no deserts in terms of vastness as portrayed in the game nor that populated.

But I digress. Despite some shortcomings of immersion for my part, this is a fun game. And if your brain doesn't get its panties in a bunch because of the conundrums, I highly recommend this.
Love the game

After about 10 hours, the game becomes boring and repetitive. When the wow effect is gone, you notice that it is a series of repetitive mini-games that become simply boring after the fortieth time. From a certain point, you can hire employees. It’s just a pity that you can’t queue up several jobs for them at once. You would like him to clean up the station when there is no car to refuel? You have to go to the computer or employee and issue such an order. He cleaned up the station and a customer is waiting at the gas pump? You have to go back to the computer or employee and change the scope of duties.

A fuel delivery or delivery of goods from the warehouse has arrived. You have to handle it yourself. Restocking shelves in a store or workshop? You run alone.

Unfortunately, I fell for optimistic reviews. I played the demo and it was short enough that I didn’t feel the boredom that comes after a few hours of play.

I really want to give this a thumbs up but there are A LOT of major issues in the game that DESTROY the game and need to be mentioned before someone buy. Let's get straight to the point, I'll just say some things that ruined the game for me.

- Game is unbalanced, this is a MAJOR issue. When I bought the game I thought let's just chill and put some gas and stuff, but no. I could literally write a whole essay about this. You CANNOT relax in this game. It IS (BARELY) possible to manage the tasks and the customers but you will be always anxious running here and there.

- The airstrip DLC. What is this? a parallel whole business to manage even tho you can't manage the gas station? This is an absolute mess, nice concept but TERRIBLE execution. If you want to focus on the Gas station you are forced to JUST IGNORE the Airstrip AND VICE VERSA. Every time that old dude pays you a visit he ALWAYS crash his airplane and you have to go like an idiot and close down the station and pick him up with some junk ahh tow truck and don't even get paid. This DLC is TERRIBLE. You don't even have the time (in-game) to check it out. Or forget the gas station while you are at the airstrip.

- Trash. 1 customer is enough to make a mess in your store. Customers throw litter on the floor and if they throw it in the trash can it goes halfway full BY 1 CUSTOMER, so not only you have to run here and there to service customers but every 2 minutes you have to empty the friggin trash cans so they don't give you a thumbs down for stinkyness. SUPER annoying and unrealistic. 

- Gameplay. Little things here and there make it even harder to enjoy this game. Having to manage every employee. Who's resting, who's working, who need payment, who's gonna clean, fuel, fix cars, cash register etc. and all these while customers are waiting. This whole system needs to be rewrote and make management easier. Also the total number of 5 employees are not even close to enough if you thought about going to check the airstrip or chill a bit and decorate or something. If their work time is over and they have to rest that's it. You have to handle the whole business by yourself. Also you are the ONLY one who have to buy stock, restock shelves, buy stock for the garage, restock garage shelves, get the delivery from the truck and put it in the warehouse that the driver couldn't do, order fuel, go open some valve when the truck arrives like the driver couldn't do either. clean garbage buy upgrades get the bulldozer and clean, go refill it every half a minute cuz it rans out of fuel and much more stuff. It's nice for a game to keep you busy but this is unbearable. Really annoying that ALL these responsibilities are yours and only. Employees should AT LEAST order stuff that are out of stock and restock shelves, mabye manage some other things here and there.

- Lack of upgrades. Your station reaches level 6 or 7 and that's it. Tasks are over, your grinding is over and now you just run what you made. It took me 9 hours to reach the maximum upgrades of the game. Should have more stuff and more upgrades to make your business run better and without all this running from you.  

- Storage, Warehouse seems like a big building. But the storage capacity is SUPER LOW and all the time you have to buy stuff get the delivery and restock while all your employees might be resting. Gasoline. You start with like what? 300L? What gas station on earth has so little gasoline capacity? Yes you can upgrade it but it's not much. Super unrealistic and another reason to be anxious. And for god shake make the driver open that valve and do his job and also the warehouse delivery driver to do the same! 

CONCLUSION:

Although the game has nice features and tons of stuff, it doesn't feel to be complete. Some games on early access are much more enjoyable and fulfilling. This feels like it's made for you to just throw your money away, with the Airstrip DLC you become SURE about this feeling. I really like the concept, but I did not enjoy the game at all because it didn't let me. It's a shame because a lot of work have been done in this and I really liked the environment. I'm dissapointed, bad work, SUPER unbalanced. I wish I could refund it and get my money back.

I would recommend this game with a caveat. It is fun, but it has problems and problems that have been around for a long time. And instead of trying to fix said problems, the devs expand into other games and other paid DLCs. I had a blast with this game but it doesn't seem polished yet and you quickly run out of things to do. I am looking forward to the other content they have planned but I'll not be expanding my library for their games or DLCs until the problems are fixed.

UPDATE: Steam has been poking me to reconsider my review now that I've dumped double-digit more hours into the game nearly a year later. 

Unfortunately my tl;dr is still entirely correct. The car wash quest feels like the developers apologizing for forgetting to put some video game in their video game. You feed trash to a chubby alligator, creating one more manual task only the player can do until they time-sink enough progress to automate it. Then you settle into the grind. Some quality-of-life improvements have made the game less jank, but it's still jank. I was genuinely in the mood to play today and settled in for a multi-hour session while listening to podcasts. It has crashed three times in an hour. 

DOUBLE UPDATE: if the car wash DLC was an apology for forgetting to put 'game' into the game, the Party Time DLC is an apology for not balancing the popularity system, making the last few achievements require over a dozen hours of grinding just to get popularity points. Also: you basically have to go into your settings and manually turn off all the "fun" add-ons they tacked on over the past year. My first time back in the game since 2022, it looked like a bad Gmod map. Every customer had Christmas hats on. The ghost of Elvis playing royalty-free butt rock floated around my gas station. Santa flew over never night. There's a gaudy UFO eternally hovering over the "party" area. 

It feels like DRAGO left a bunch of empty space open with the idea they would add more stuff later, but then had no real vision for what to do with said open space, so they made a habit of putting the first thing that'd come to mind there. Giant dauchsund-snake in the hills? Sure. $60,000 giant rocking chair that has no effect on traffic increase? Sure. Dinosaur tourist trap you can't even walk over to? Why not. The game just starts to look actively tackier, and that's saying a LOT about a game that has MULTIPLE Elon Musk NPCs walking around. 

On to the original review: 

Gas Station Simulator is secretly an Early Access title that was released as a full game. The fact that there have had to be such drastic updates and balancing tweaks done within days of the first drop should be a big red flag. They also seem to be prioritizing fixing content visible to the people playing in the first couple hours (e.g. streamers, YouTubers, and not-simulator-savvy journalists parachuting in for a look but not committing to a full game). The biggest example so far is them claiming to have fixed terrain clipping through the gas station floor. DRAGO did indeed fix that, but only the piece of terrain visible through the floor if you haven't spent a few hours upgrading the station. As of this review there's still a jagged polygon of ground poking through the floor in an area only accessible after two upgrades (where people who can still refund the game likely won't see). 

tl;dr: while this has far more polish than most shovelware "simulator" games, this is, at the end of the day, one of those shovelware titles cobbled together from mechanics and ideas seen in other titles by the same developer/publishing company. 

The fact DRAGO, a tiny little Polish developer, will release six "simulator" games in the next year should be evidence this isn't the fun wacky sim game you heard about on Kotaku. The only people who'll be genuinely entertained by this haven't tried out simulator games since Playway started flooding the market with House Flipper clones. 

For a full 4k word review see my blog: https://gavingaddis.com/2021/09/19/gas-station-simulator/

Welcome to our excursion into the charming world of Gas Station Simulator, a game that stands as proof that not all exciting journeys begin in far-off lands or epic fantasy realms. Developed by DRAGO Entertainment, this intriguing simulator offers players the chance to experience the ins and outs of running their very own gas station.

Gameplay:
Gas Station Simulator delivers an experience that is as quirky as it is immersive. You begin with a dilapidated gas station in the middle of a desert, and it is up to you to bring it back to life. From refueling cars and repairing engines to restocking shelves and cleaning restrooms, the game challenges you to manage multiple tasks while continually expanding and improving your station. Its in-depth management mechanics and the variety of tasks keep the gameplay fresh and engaging.

Audio and Music:
The sound design in Gas Station Simulator is surprisingly detailed. From the clinking of cash registers and the hum of car engines to the chit-chat of customers, the game effectively recreates the bustling environment of a busy gas station. The soundtrack, while not particularly memorable, serves as a pleasant background that doesn’t intrude on the gameplay.

Story:
While Gas Station Simulator lacks a formal storyline, the game does an excellent job of storytelling through gameplay. Your progression serves as your narrative as you turn a run-down gas station into a thriving business, creating a satisfying sense of achievement.

Difficulty:
The difficulty in Gas Station Simulator lies in the juggling of tasks and keeping your customers happy. As your station grows, so does the complexity of your responsibilities. The game also features a day-night cycle and random events which can add unexpected challenges.

Price:
Considering the depth of gameplay and the amount of content, Gas Station Simulator is priced reasonably. It offers good value for money, particularly for fans of simulation games.

Critique:
While Gas Station Simulator offers an engaging experience, it isn't without flaws. The game could benefit from more diverse customer interactions and tasks. Additionally, some players might find the early game a bit slow before the gas station starts to expand.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Gas Station Simulator is a quirky and immersive simulator that successfully makes the ordinary task of running a gas station fun and engaging. It offers an in-depth management system and a variety of tasks that ensure the gameplay remains fresh. Although it has room for improvement, the overall experience is a satisfying and enjoyable one. So, roll up your sleeves, grab that fuel pump, and get ready to jump into the extraordinary world of ordinary life with Gas Station Simulator.

I played this game after seeing it advertised and watching a youtuber 100% it closer to when it launched.  It is an oddly addictive game and if you just play it to enjoy it, it is quite fun. I love how over the top the cut scenes are and it makes some of the early on grinding worth it. Also how the game just throws achievements at you for the first five or so hours of this game is fun as well. It is fairly realistic as you have to spend money to make money, sometimes with very little profit margin, rather than some simulators where after a certain point you are just endlessly making money. The AI pathing and things like that could be slightly improved however it is still a fun game and looks surprising well graphically for what it is. Decorating is super fun and I love the interactive decorations, it just sucks most of them serve no real purpose and just halt your progress. I would recommend this for anyone who wants a fairly mindless little game to play and have fun with. 

In all my reviews on games that I 100% I will mention whether I recommend this 100% or not. If you are looking for a grindy simulator achievement, this is the one for you. It is not as grindy as it used to be with the free party time DLC (before that people were grinding well over 100+ hours for level 10 popularity). Depending on how you go about it, it should take you 20-40 hours to complete, and most of that will be grinding the popularity levels, grinding one of your employees to level 10 in all skills, and paying off uncles loan.  Most other achievements are just thrown at you for completing certain tasks and buying upgrades.

Eh. The premise of the game is super satisfying, but.... 1. The micromanagement of every little thing (paying employees, ordering goods for four different sections of the station, assigning employees every single time to the job I always have them do, having to turn on and off the sections of the station based on the reset time of the individual employees, making sure there's enough available water for the car wash), 2. The performance of the game is... mediocre at best. You can tell it struggles. 3. The have all these little elements to the station (mini golf course, monolith, remote control race cars) but none of them have any actual purpose beyond little Easter egg add-ins. 4. You have this loft thing that get bigger as you unlock larger warehouse space but you can't do anything with it. 

Am I saying that I want the game to manage everything for me? No. But seriously, the game becomes a chore at a certain point. Employees should have shifts, they should have assigned tasks, goods should be ordered automatically (at least to a certain extent), I shouldn't have to keep shredding trash to make sure there's enough water for the automatic car wash, I shouldn't have to turn on or off portions of the station, it should be based on whether or not an employee is working there.

They added DLC and it kind of sucks. The only one that really matters is the party one, but its weird. There's a countdown and a bus pulls up with people and they rock out then leave. The popularity of the party is based on baskets that you fill with random items. If that confused you then you are not alone. I have no idea what they were thinking. 

The game, as is, entertains you for about three hours before you start getting bored with having to manage everything. Obviously it's about managing a gas station but elements of the management should advance and some of the little tasks should be automated in the end game. If they made it that employees were paid and given a schedule then this game would easily be great.
One of the best job sim style games out there. Plenty of character and a good atmosphere. There are a few bugs yet to work out but nothing completely game breaking.

Before you buy: Please take a look at their announcements!

This game here is sort of fun, still a lot of bugs, but playable. Instead of fixing the games already out, they plan on building a whole universe here, which isn't bad if you would listen to your community and care about your games and that sadly isn't the case. They dump out announcements with false promises, start developing a series of other games while the games already out, are still lacking a lot of care and love.

And to top it all off, now you have to buy two more games to get new features for existing games like 'memorable customers' which should be part of the core game, since there isn't anything memorable here except that annoying Dennis. We are not even talking about a DLC, but an entire new game, probably also riddled with paid DLCs.
Plus there will be penalties for certain aspects of the entire universe those games are taking place, which already sounds like they were rushed out the door. For instance: In Gas Station Simulator you get the objective to break into your customers car trunks as a side hustle which is non optional. Also there are challenges you have to do in order to increase your fame which is breaking into trunks. (Fame is needed in order to get more customers into you gas station and to progress further in the game)
Now they want to penalize it in their other games, losing customers in the motel or dinner.

This alone should be a warning enough, because it's a huge design oversight, which wouldn't have happened if they would actually know what they were doing.

It's not quite often when a simulator does this: recognizes that it is, in fact, a game. This simulator, while buggy and not very polished, is a fun and time consuming task-based game where it allows you full creativity in how you accomplish those tasks. Have trash to throw out? You can either walk to the dumpster, throw it out normally, OR...you can climb onto the roof of your gas station and launch it full force and (hopefully) make it in the dumpster. My first time playing I spent THREE continuously without getting up or diverting my attention to my phone, which is quite uncommon. Only reason I stopped was because it was 3 AM and I was tired. Fun, fluid gameplay that doesn't limit you by time restrictions such as excessive animations. Want to go crazy fast? Go for it. Want to relax and take things slow? Can do that too. 7/10, would play for another three hours again.

The DLC is even buggier than the main game. Even if you disable, uninstall, or do not own the DLC, the game prompts you to complete it, breaking the game and preventing progress.

I spent so long trying to find a fix or workaround for the controller issues (I'm disabled and cannot use keyboard and mouse), and then again for the DLC railroading, that I had the game open for too long and am now no longer eligible for a refund.

There is a lot to do, all of which is shallow and done better by other games. The polished look and sense of freedom to make your station what you will, as presented in the trailer, ends up being much less so: everything is locked behind "challenges" and grind. You end up rushing around a lot while also being completely tied to the quest progression system - even when common sense would suggest you don't HAVE to in order to do various things. Well, the game sez otherwise, so snap to it, drudge.

This sense of drudgery has no shortcut, either, despite a "loan shark" mechanic. Which I didn't appreciate being forcibly introduced to. You don't have a choice: your first loan is imposed on you, impossible to pay back in time, and ends with a fairly vicious, unavoidable beatdown. But even if you go ahead and take out the biggest loan you can after that, you're only slightly accelerating your ability to make more money than you spend on the business. It's really only useful for the occasional emergency bailout, so I ended up avoiding it entirely.

Another annoying mechanic is the kid who will periodically come around to deface the place.  Welcome to a new layer of pointless drudgework, which serves only to interrupt the actually useful drudgework. You're supposed to hit them with a random object, usually a bag of garbage or something, so he runs away. Well, he doesn't. He just goes to the next target point to keep on defacing, so you have to hit him multiple times with garbage that will bounce FAR away after you hit him with it. You are NOT allowed to just use the damn broom that you use to sweep the floor and which is on you at all times, for no apparent reason. All of this means that you will end up re-painting your station quite a bit - oh, and that's also a boring, shallow minigame about keeping a marker "in the green" (supposedly representing paint roller pressure).

I think what decided me against playing this any further was that when it came time to make improvements to the grounds, there was zero choice involved. I could buy, or not buy, the single improvement for a given area, like "tombstone car displays" and palm trees. The big lovely sign out front? You don't even say yea or nay; the game AUTOMATICALLY renovates that for you, like it or not.

After six hours of gameplay, this just seems like a chore, with no indication of a breakout point where it starts being fun (or at least open-ended). If I'm going to take on what amounts to an actual job of pumping gas, scanning groceries, and slinging tires, then I at least want a SEMBLANCE of creative freedom regarding the place I bought expressly to renovate.

If you've played Weed Shop, you'll have this game down within a few minutes, however, the more you play, the more you notice features missing. Yes, you grind your way to automation and employees, but damn, you have to micro manage every little aspect! More automation please!

A warning for new players. The AI in this game is dumb and you cannot schedule shifts. Each time someone finishes a shift you'll be dipping into the PC to find someone who's not resting. You'll also have to chase the cleaner around as they are  more than useless, even detrimental. If you're not already fed up of cleaning up after the cleaner, your shop will be sprayed with 'NASA rockets' by the local kid, which adds nothing to the game... and when you've really had enough, a sandstorm blows through every 60ish minutes and all the cars get stuck... In a buggy, non comical way!! How do you fix it? Using a awful skid steer that has enough fuel to last 2 minutes. You'll be spending most of your time pushing cars out of the way with your broom, to hit the pile 'Just right' to get the button to scoop said sand pile.

The game is good... It could be up their with Weed Shop, if only the devs added quality of life features, like scheduling, more employees, automatic product purchasing, a warehouse employee to unload the truck, automatic shelf stacking... and got rid of stupid things like clearing up after spray paint, sand storms, and having to dip into the sewer to feed the alligator every 30 minutes. The devs think it's a 'fun way' to slow you down. It's not fun, it's repetitive and annoying.

I understand why they added these 'annoying' features. I get they are there to slow the player down. But, it's only take me 15 hours to complete the game. That's it, 15 hours... done. Is there more content? Yes. Is it DLCs? Yes. Should it be base game content? Absolutely!

If you get this game on offer, it's worth it. If you're looking for a game that kills a weekend, this game is for you. If you want a game that you can happily manage, semi-AFK while watching TV... This is not the game for you. What you need, is Weed Shop.

Devs, stop trying to 'slow us down' by adding annoying features. Give us automation and remove the astonishingly 'over 
tuned' brutal and repetitive tasks. The whole point in a business simulator is eventually being the boss and watching your employees work while you adjust the plant pot in your office!

Fun game, You could argue that this isn't really a "Simulator", However given that there aren't any other Gas Station Sims where you slowly upgrade the station, manage product inventory, shop cleanliness as well as layout, this is the best we have. There are several little mini games to complete tasks such as Checking Out customers, Filling cars with Gas, or maintaining the Mechanic shop.
The Car Wash I would say is the least mini game of it all, as you're free to tackle the dirt in any way you like however it does feel reminiscent of Power wash Sim but a clunky attempt.

To max out the gas station it does feel a little bit grindy, the good part to this is most of the way to the max level, you have goals to complete or story missions to complete, so it doesn't feel totally tedious but it's there.

Not all is perfect in this game, it can get a little buggy.
Sandstorms should be optional in gameplay settings as it is an annoying mechanic, creating sand piles which can lead to cars getting bugged out. Luckily there is a reset functionality incase NPC's get bugged out 
(kinda ridiculous changes couldn't have been made to negate the button entirely but oh well, ai will bug and you'll use the button eventually, its a norm for gameplay too)

On a 5800x 3070 ti with 32gb of ram I barely average 60 fps, optimization is still quite bad but it is playable.

Overall though, the slight bugs aside, its a fun game. Not as much of a Simulator as other Simulators go, as many strive for a more realistic approach, I would say this game is a bit cartoony and doesn't take itself too seriously while also giving you things like Employees, inventory management, product management as well as fluctuating prices for said product. Ingame economy is OK, not the worst.

EDIT New Review Note:  Well, my original review is below, but I received an email from the developer saying I should check it out again.  I have no problem with that, bugs can be fixed. Was just walking in place by the drivers door and wouldn't do anything.  So just like my previous review I have to stick with this game is a cash grab bug and I can't recommend it.  I didn't even want to risk checking if the other concerns were fixed if the very first customer refuel interaction was broken.  That's just 10-15 minutes into the game and already I couldn't progress again.

Update:
As of April 28, 2023, I've booted it up again and managed to play for an extended amount of time without any mishaps. 

Further thoughts about the game:

1. With the new DLCs, I still find myself being stretched thin trying to keep everything stocked, dealing with traders, and generally keeping things running, even with hired workers.

2. There seems to be a lack of ceiling lighting options. The station gets very dim at night and it's not easy to see things.

3. I think there is some confusion over the final negotiating card in the air strip dlc and how to unlock it. I've finished the upgrades for the barn, but I have yet to unlock this card.

Overall, it's gotten better than the last time I've played, and I hope it will only keep improving.

Good:
-Funny car flips with the mop.
-Easy access to close all parts of the station with numerous ways to make money.
-Having staff to help increase profits without running around crazily.
-Achievements and leveling for the gas station as well as the other businesses such as the car wash and the workshop. 
-Party bus is great, as well as the party spot. Party spot helps increase popularity pretty fast.

Meh:
-Dust storms make it annoying to get rid of sand piles to avoid traffic buildups, though it does give challenge.
-Gas tank storage is in the way of shop customer traffic and causes lots of horns when getting gas delivered.
-Repetition of customers, understandably but still sad.
-Staff suck at cleaning the shop and bathrooms, take forever to do so, and do not seem to empty trash which irritates customers.
-Staff also do not help increase popularity which is fair but would be nice if you had all working and it increased because you had all rather than it more likely decreasing popularity. Makes it hard to get higher levels quickly due to that. Gotta do everything yourself.

Edit:  Well the game isn't crashing anymore but man is this airplane dlc a pain in the butt.  There is no option to turn it off and it story locks the game.  I didn't buy the dlc but somehow I have access to it(?).  So you're stuck dealing with this irritating stuff and I'm not having a great time.  I've also had to broom corral two cars that were intent on driving the wrong way and blocking the gas station.  So still buggy.  Not enough changes/improvements to make me change my recommendation.

I've only been playing for a few hours and I've encountered several game-breaking bugs including being unable to level up my gas station (the button does nothing when clicked), being unable to unscrew tires and stuck in the repair animation even after "resetting character," being unable to clean the conveyor belt, dirt piling up inside of the terrain which impacts cleanliness, and more. On top of all of this the game has absolutely abysmal controller support and sometimes the game will give tutorials with half in controller support and half in keyboard support on the same window. This game feels like alpha phase. The devs pushed this game out knowing that it was incomplete. This is the second worst controller support I've ever experienced in a game with controller support.

Now with all of that being said, the game has nice features, good graphics, pleasant interaction and good action pace. Unfortunately I would not recommend playing it when you encounter a reload-or-quit bug every 10 minutes.

I'm writing this review because this game and the reviews about it can be VERY misleading. First of all this IS NOT a simulator. It's an arcade game full of repetitive mini games. It's hardly a freedom factory either as so many things are dictated. The corny and dated level system does not belong in something to claim to be a simulator and the story and voice acting are so spine tinglingly cringy it flat out does not belong in a simulator. The game also seems to have a propensity for erasing your saves. I've left the game after saving multiple times only to return and see all those saves have disappeared. After doing some investigating it turns out this has been a problem with the game for some time. Pretty big problem! 

The game plays and feels very tacky with it's arcade style and you have to race around like a crackhead because everything is so fast paced and to a ridiculously unrealistic extent. This is because the game is 100% an ARCADE GAME. Even though I only paid 20 bucks I regret buying it and wish I could get my money back.

As a person who enjoys simulations of all stripes and varieties, this one is pretty good for its cost.  What you lack in story, you gain in mystery as you walk around and find random things that are part of the game.  I like this game for the same reason I like House Flipper: simplicity.  You run a gas station in a part of the US I'm very familiar with: outside of Vegas.  Although still glitchy and not everything is customizable, enough of it is to warrant the price.  Try this game if you like other simulations that aren't too complicated to enjoy, and yet could benefit from a spreadsheet on your second monitor.

A major con that can be fixed, is how often my game crashes.  I don't have a slow rig, and take great pride in my computer's ability to play very large games (think Sims 4 including all expansions) very well.  For this reason, I'm taking a break from this game and trying some others until the devs catch up and fix remaining bugs.  For about $20 bucks, I got a good amount of entertainment and look forward to coming back to this game later.

For the price, one heck of a game.
- Lots of stuff to do,
- Lots of customization (like paints, decorations, tile, etc.), so you can really make your station your own.
- A good bit of humor. 

But, there are some in game issues....

1. Until you hire some help, you'll literally be doing EVERYTHING at this place. It can be overwhelming;  Pumping gas, tending the register, keeping up inventory, cleaning up the place/picking up trash, general maintenance (sometimes offsite a bit), ordering merchandise and fuel, washing cars, fixing cars, running vandals off the property, unloading trucks, etc. etc.

2. Graphics are a bit dated, but it is an indie game, after all.

3. Unfortunately, there are some minor bugs. Nothing super bad, just mildly annoying. For example, every once in a while, you'll get out of a menu, and suddenly your field of vision will get stuck at crotch level and you can't fix it until you reload the game. Sometimes, employees that work the register will just stop working and stand there doing nothing. I once got stuck in a dumpster for a few seconds, too. 
---------------------
All in all, a good game, though. I can definitely see some replayability here.

Edit - After the dev response to my review I jumped back in and tried again. The car horn audio switch doesn't seem to work. With car horn set to "off" they still honked constantly. One of my hired employee's went missing and when I tried to tell her to do a different job from the in store PC she told me she was busy and couldn't do that. Eventually during my second play session I had a CTD. While not a terrible experience, I still can't recommend this game.

This isn't my first time playing GSS(Gas Station Simulator) 
I played on another steam account on my old pc; i7 7700 cpu/ GTX 1080TI gpu with 16g RAM. The game constantly experienced framerate issues, especially late game. I ended up writing a review at the time and even went to the GSS discord server to try to see what was going on- that was 2 years ago. I ended up buying a new pc; an i9 13900kf cpu, 4070TI gpu, Asus z790p motherboard, 32g Titan RAM, all on a firecuda ssd (8g read/write) 

I say all this to inform you all that even with the top of the line pc, it really doesn't matter. The game still experiences frame rate issues, it constantly crashes whenever you get gas services going while having more than 2 parking lots(too many cars jam and just crashes the game), the game informs you too many lights will crash the game, cars get stuck on everything from the smallest pebble to the NPC that drives it. Sometimes car tires get stuck on the fuel pumps so you have to go to the warehouse to "UFO" the entire map away then wait 4 minutes just to have a decent amount of things to do again, just for the game to crash 10 minutes later.

 Its a fun game, don't get me wrong- but the aspect of doing chores for a game then it crashing and deleting the last 15 minutes of progress every time sends me the wrong message- especially when the game is considered "Finished/complete" with an absurd amount of game breaking glitches. I usually don't write reviews, but people need to know what they're in for. 

You have about 2-4 hours of fun game play before the entire game shits out its own ass. I give this game 4/10, buy it on sale for probably $5. You have to consider the infinite amount of free games on steam with infinite amount of replayability- all for the high cost of FREE, but GSS charges $20 so you can actively hate your life
After the updates, the game runs perfectly and I didn't experience any FPS drops. Great game.

Gas Station Simulator is an unusual and fun simulation that puts you in the role of a gas station owner. Players are in charge of everything from stock management, fuel purchasing, equipment maintenance and customer service.

The game mechanics are very realistic and players must be careful when planning their business. They will have to keep track of their expenses and sales, manage their employees and make sure their customers feel comfortable. Players can also invest in new equipment, such as fast charging stations and car cosmetics, which will help them improve the customer experience and increase their profits.

The game's graphics are great, with detailed vehicle models and environments that look very realistic. The controls are fairly simple and intuitive, so players can easily get into the game and start having fun.

The game also offers many challenges and tasks to keep players engaged in the game, although some of them can be quite difficult. However, this just adds another dimension to the game and increases its play value.

Overall, Gas Station Simulator is a great choice for those looking for a realistic and fun business simulation. With a large selection of equipment, realistic graphics and many challenges, this game will provide many hours of fun and business success.
amazing!!!!!!!
good soup

Gas Station Simulator does a thing not enough other games do, just let you be in the moment. It's been my go-to game for a few weeks now when I just want to focus on a task and be rewarded with incremental progression. It is a buggy mess at times, but hilariously the devs included tools to help you combat this, including a broom that can flip cars, or a ufo switch that resets all cars and npc on the map. The decorating is fun without being too time intensive. The devs were even nice enough to give you the option to turn off a really annoying part of the game if you don't want to deal with it. There's a lot hiding under the skin of this game too. There's little mini-games everywhere, you can play guitar, race rc cars, or just try to set high scores by lobbing trash across the map. It really is a great game to help you zone out and just chill. Do recommend. I was pleasantly surprised at how often I think about playing this game. And if you're feeling a little overwhelmed mid game, my suggestion is to get an employee to run the register, and one to run the garage. All the other tasks are incredibly easy to manage on your own with those two out of the way.

Not so much a gas station simulator, more a collection of mini games with a gas station theme. And that's fine - there's plenty to keep you busy, plenty of customisation available and a few simple management style mechanics such as keeping stock levels and buying at optimum prices. It'll need a bit more content before full release - there's not much to do or look forward to from Level 6 onwards aside from grinding the same stuff you've been grinding before but this time with nothing new to look forward to as a reward. That doesn't stop me recommending the game, it's early access after all.

When I first started playing this game, it had just been released for less than five days and I was hooked. At this price point, there was really nothing to criticize, so I gave it a positive review, hoping that the developers would continue to update and improve the game.

However, despite the game's terrible optimization, the developers chose to release paid DLC instead of fixing the bugs in the base game. Signs of their lack of enthusiasm for the game were evident, as the game would only run at 30fps with a 3070Ti graphics card, and there were frequent lag spikes. It seemed that they were either selling a barely functional game just to make money or simply ignoring the game altogether. When they released several DLCs without addressing the game's performance issues, I changed my review to a negative one, so that other players could be aware of these problems before buying.

Unexpectedly, in 2023, the developers replied to my review, asking me to try the game again and explaining that they had made improvements. With a little bit of trust, I gave the game another chance and found that it had indeed been significantly optimized, with some quality-of-life improvements as well. Overall, I think the game is pretty good.

My advice to the developers is to take your game seriously, as that's the only way to achieve long-term success. Players are smart and discerning, and those who love your game are more than willing to support you. But if you try to cut corners and ignore your game's issues, you'll end up losing more than you gain. As can be seen from the negative reviews that followed each update, the public is aware of this.

"Gas Station Simulator" is a fun and engaging game that puts players in the role of a gas station owner. The game challenges players to manage their gas station, serving customers, and expanding their business to become the best gas station in town.

One of the standout features of "Gas Station Simulator" is its attention to detail. The game's environments are beautifully rendered, with a variety of gas station equipment and facilities that create a sense of immersion that draws the player in. The game's character models and animations are also incredibly lifelike, adding to the overall sense of realism.

Another aspect of the game that sets it apart is its deep and engaging gameplay mechanics. Players must manage their gas station, hiring employees, setting prices, and maintaining their equipment to keep customers happy and increase profits. The game's resource management mechanics are also excellent, with a variety of resources to collect and sell in order to make a profit.

However, what really makes "Gas Station Simulator" special is its sense of humor and fun. The game doesn't take itself too seriously, with plenty of quirky characters and humorous situations to keep players entertained. The game's various challenges and missions are also fun and engaging, adding to the overall sense of enjoyment.

Overall, "Gas Station Simulator" is a fantastic game that is sure to provide countless hours of entertainment. With detailed environments, engaging gameplay mechanics, and a fun and humorous atmosphere, it is a must-play for anyone who loves simulation games or just wants to run their own gas station.

Very short game, not much to do.  I feel that I completed near everything in ~ 15 hours of gameplay.

Revised 3/29/2023:
A developer responded "It's been a while since your review and a lot of things have changed, we've improved some mechanics or added new options."

I looked through the release notes since I last played and nothing meaningful was added except DLC as far as I can tell.  But I played through the game anyway, which is still buggy and borderline unplayable.  I had to reset my character twice and the world a handful of times.  I hit a bug bad enough that upon reloading the game, it crashes.

This game has such potential, but it is still in beta as far as I can tell.  They are now adding DLC to a broken game.  I don't recommend picking this up unless you want to do some quality verification for the developer.

UPDATE (03/29/2023) - Per developer's request, I tried this game again today. I didn't get any update, apparently. Game play is very laggy, at best. Also, there is this very annoying question mark on anything I look at...it just floats there, and I cannot click on it or remove it or anything. Still stuck on moving sand piles ad nauseam. I REALLY wanted to like this game. I REALLY wish I could get a refund, as I will never play it. 
**********************************************************************************************************

I bought this game after playing and enjoying the demo. I should have realized that there is a reason you cannot use the front loader, "Rudy" in the demo.
The ONLY thing this game is letting me do is removing sand piles after sand piles, driving them somewhere else, and then driving back to the gas station, to fill up with gas, and then rinse repeat. I cannot do anything else on this game but this. Other than that, the game crashing at least twice before it will start. 

IF you want to buy this game, based on the demo, buyer beware. It only lets you play the fun parts of the game, but not of the endless sand pile removal requirement. 

At this point, I cannot recommend this game at all. In fact, I've requested a refund, even though it's been past 2 weeks.

It started out nicely, but quickly turned into a chore-machine. I like business games. This is not a business game. This is a sweep the floor-game. A limit on number of employees (also they're inefficient and need constant assignment and reassignment) makes it so that you can forget about being business smart. No. Just work work work work work.

Edit: DON'T BUY THE GAME. In light of comment by developer, that didn't really answer my comments, I skimmed through the news of the game and found nothing that adressed my initial complaints. But I did see a lot of marketing, and suspect that the devs also use comments as marketing. They try to make my review look old, butit is not. I won't be bothered testing the game again until it's made likely to have been drastically changed.

I enjoyed the base concept of the game. Running a gas station, repairing cars, managing the shop and managing hired help. Due to some bugs occuring every now and then, I certainly advise to regularly save the game.
For those, who want to 100% this game in case of achievements, you may want to save the game regularly if your game tends to crash some times.

As simulator games go this hits every mark on the tedium brain dead mentality you want in something to kill time and wind down after a long day. The progression system is surprisingly in depth for a game of this type and nothing is thrown at you too quickly. Its absolutely possible to manage the station without loans after the first 4-5 upgrades once the "tutorial" phase wanes a bit. I adore the ability to have a bit of tedium while each day that passes also leaves a feeling of accomplishment in a job well done. the mechanics work best with mouse and keyboard as its not greatly optimized for a controller, especially running the check out line. in my almost 30 hours of game play this will probably remain my "before bed" game for at minimum another 30 hours. Props to the developer for doing only a few things but doing them intentionally and with great effort!

The game can be fun but there's just too many unpolished elements that make it feel sloppy.
Spark Plugs are labelled inconsistently in the Delivery Screen and also are awkward to pick up from their holder.

There's no snap to grid/wall function and it's way too easy to accidentally pick up things, even worse there is no cancel/undo function. 

Workers don't remember what they did before going on a break and don't have a task queue system so if you want them to stop serving a customer on the cash register, you have to spam press it until they actually finish the current customer. 

Scrolling on the delivery order menu is bugged so if you need to scroll down to remove something, good luck. On that note actually, why does it need to be a pop up window? Why can't the order menu have both products and the current basket on the same screen, there's definitely enough screen space to do so.

Pathing is also bugged so if you have a larger shop and place ice cream freezers in the middle, the customers will get stuck on them and can't path around them. 

Picking up items is awkward as sometimes they won't actually move, or you can't rotate larger items to get them through a door. 

Also the garage aspect is extremely frustrating, why on earth does practically every car need 2-3 tyres replaced at the same time? There was even a run where I had multiple cars needing all 4 tyres replaced. Keeping up with inventory for this part of the game is an absolute nightmare. 

It's such a shame as there is a good game buried in this but it really needs a lot more polish but it doesn't seem like they will do it.

Gas Station Simulator is a game that is simply unplayable, even on the best computers. I was really excited to try out the game and take on the challenge of running my own gas station, but unfortunately, it was a complete waste of time.

From the moment I launched the game, I was greeted with lag and stuttering graphics, making it almost impossible to even navigate the menu. Even after tweaking the settings and trying various configurations, the game remained sluggish and unresponsive.

I was incredibly disappointed by this, as I had heard great things about the game from friends and online reviews. But sadly, the game's technical issues make it impossible to enjoy. And even when the game did run somewhat smoothly, the gameplay was boring and repetitive, with no real challenge or depth.

I cannot recommend Gas Station Simulator to anyone, no matter how much they may be interested in the premise of the game. It's simply not worth the frustration and disappointment of trying to play it.

I didn't expect to get this caught up in such an essentially simple game, but I really did.  I like the concept, and the graphics and concept are really well done.  It catches me the same way Civilfixation does -- I just want to keep going for that one little goal more, and I like the organization and the challenge.  I do wish there was some kind of a short guide to let me know what some of the employee reactions mean -- I've seen them have speech balloons like the ones that the customers have, but I'm not exactly sure if that's an indication of lack of morale, hating what they're doing, or what.   

As someone who lives in a duststorm area myself, I have to give the creators credit for thinking of something that was right on the money.  I do wish you had a pellet gun or something to shoot at Dennis!

I understand that crashes were common when the party bus came by; apparently, there's been some work done there, because while I have a moment or two of very slow bogging, it snaps back.  The game stability does still need some work, though; I have experienced several game crashes, though the autosave has generally been fairly close.  

I see that ice cream vending is an option for the employees, but I don't yet see how to do that.  I'm in search of the accolade where you get your employees up to level 10 on everything.  BTW, I liked the hiring process and the backgrounds, too.  

Overall, a fun concept and a fun game, and a nice break from my usual shoot 'em ups. Thanks so much!

I want to stress that I enjoy this game and I want to see it do well. I also want to stress that because you or I enjoy something,  that doesnt make it automatically good. I love Payday 2, for example, but its a disaster. 

This game is walking a fine line between utter brilliance and complete incompetence. It is filled with great ideas but there's something off about all of them. The best way I have to describe this game is; you wished for a gas station simulator, and the monkey's paw curled. 

Easily the best parts of the game are in the early stages. Building up your station from a smelly shack and turning it into a profitable business is well done, engaging and paced really well. Once you hit mid to late game, you start to notice some weird ticks and the unholy amount of bugs. 

The way cars arrive to the fuel pumps is scripted. If I fill all three up at the same time, they will arrive a few minutes later, all together, at the same time again. When a car arrives for repairs in your garage, the front right tire will ALWAYS be flat. The game tells you that you have to keep the bathrooms clean or customers will complain. This only amounts to sweeping the floor free of dust as you never actually have to clean the bathrooms themselves. Theres an RC track located outside the gas station. Im not sure why its here because once the station gets going, you will never have time to use it. On top of that, even with employees, the game starts to get frantic the more you add to it, because employees cant do everything and once you open all possible parking spaces, the cashier job is essentially endless and youll be ordering more product multiple times a day to keep up with every customer buying a weeks worth of snacks over and over. 

These are just some of the things Ive noticed. I notice more every time I play. 

I really want to stress that I am in Drago's corner. I want to see them do well. I think they have some great ideas but it is very evident that not much care went into making this game. Several years on and it is still very rough. It is full of pre purchased assets, some of which don't really go together. For example, on your newspaper stand, you can sell crisp fresh newspapers right next to a crumpled magazine that looks like it was dug out of the trash. Im also not sure what year it is as every single person drives a classic car from the 50s and 60s from both Europe and America, but Im also surrounded by relatively new tech such as computers and automatic car washes while my uncle wears a suit from the 40s, while I sell modern day styled snacks and drinks. I know Ive seen this circuit box before. Ive seen it everywhere, Ive turned it on countless times in phasmophobia.

The biggest show of lackadaisical devving is the Christmas event. At the time of writing it is currently March and despite a Valentines day event coming and going, the Christmas event is still in full swing. Santa has flown over head more times than I can count and Ive gotten so used to the customers wearing festive hats that Ive stopped seeing them. Its March, Drago. I know we are playing a country hick and they typically dont take down the christmas lights but can we please put santa out of his misery? 

My biggest concern with Drago is that they dont seem to focus on one game and making it good. If you look at their store page they are working on about NINE games at once. While they appear to be using the same asset bundles between them, theres no way there can be any quality between that many projects at once. Even AAA companies only work on one or two games at once. Not NINE. This is on top of the games that they have already released, like this one, that still needs polish and boast about upcoming features. Drago, please just slow down and focus on one at a time. Releasing half baked games, like food truck sim, is not going to hold a fanbase for very long.

Edit: After writing this review, Drago announced that they are "proud" to be working on even more projects. If you look at their store page there is now a whopping 12 upcoming games. This is on top of the 3 they have already released. These games are sitting at mixed except for Gas Station Simulator and feel more like early beta to even alpha stages instead of finished games. Now they are working on 12 at once. Remember that scene from Spongebob where Neptune challenges Spongebob to a cook off and Neptune pumps out a pyramid of burgers but they are all nasty, meanwhile Spongebob cooks a single one and its so amazing it moves Neptune to turn him into a god? 

Go watch Spongebob, Drago.
it's just a big mess that the dev's doesn't fix

I love this game more than I would have expected. I never wanted to own a gas station or live in the desert but here we are. A lot of reviews talk about the many glitches but the vast majority of them are just silly, like this one customer who got stuck standing on the soda shelf. She stayed there until I closed the station. A few times a delivery truck got stuck and I had to reload from an earlier save since neither the car reset button or restarting the game helped, but it's customary to save often since no game is glitch-free. A lot of people don't like the party bus but it is one of my favourite things! Being able to shut down the repair shop, the car wash , and even the fueling stations from the PC is extremely useful when the onslaught of customers arrives. I don't want to give any spoilers but there are moments of zaniness and unexpected occurrences which add a delightful quality to the game. I play on PC and the controls all work perfectly. The devs thoughtfully added some in-game fixes for when certain things go wrong, like reset buttons for cars, people, and some of the equipment. 

I have severe PTSD and doing repetitive tasks to build up the station helps alleviate my ever-present anxiety, and this game serves that purpose for me extremely well. The feeling of accomplishment when completing an upgrade and redecorating is gratifying and keeps me coming back to the game.  The graphics are gorgeous too. The desert environment is stunning, and it's obvious the devs took a lot of time creating it. The whole atmosphere takes on a liminal quality during the twilight hours, and sometimes it's a bit spooky, which I love. I don't have any significant complaints, but I do wish there was more of an immersive story, like perhaps getting to know some of the clientele. Aside from that, the game is highly playable and I recommend it, and all of the DLC.

Well, the graphics are absolutely horrible, the gameplay feels really quanky, the music is boring and repetitive and the humor is childish -- but despite all these downsides and quirks, it's still a fun and somewhat relaxing game, that can keep you busy and entertained for a long time.

My main issue with this game is that it's core gameplay "cannibalizes" itself over the time: When you start a new game and are left alone with that gas station, there is a lot of stuff to do: fuel cars, handle the cash register, repair cars, bring the trash out, etc -- that's the "weird job simulator" part of the game that is actually fun. However, once your gas station attracts more customers, you are more or less forced to hire employees, which perform these simple tasks for you -- and now all that you are actually left with is the ordering of fuels and goods (food, drinks, car parts) at the lowest price possible, which turns the game into an actual "trader simulator" and unfortunately, this economic part doesn't really feel fun to me and it is not possible to let an employee handle this trading stuff...

Still, I have enjoyed the game for dozens of hours and I can definitely recommend trying it out -- if you can live with the graphics, that is.

So far, the game is fun. It's really satisfying to clean up and restore this old gas station and the surrounding areas. It's house flipper core gameplay with money-making minigames and the writing that frames it is really funny IMO.

That being said, the controller support is incredibly bad. I've only seen a handful of tutorial prompts that actually show the controller button instead of the keyboard. Some activities are fine with the controller. Some, like the checking out minigame, are impossible. You can't really navigate the main menu with a controller. Trying to go through the computer menu with a controller is so hard; selected items are very subtle so you don't always know what you're selecting, trying to order quantities of anything is a nightmare. It's obvious that the game was made with keyboard and mouse in mind and after it was kinda retrofitted for controller but not very well.

Overall, I like this game. But there's definitely some things to keep note of going in. Mainly - the bugs and the absolute grind fest this is. While I really enjoy the multiple different things available to do, the amount of times I've had glitches happen is frustrating. The party area with the free party DLC causes the party bus to frequently get stuck, depending on where you place your register the queue can very easily break. I had my line going through the bathroom stalls at one point.  You can't place the shelves however you want to or customers or your own employees will get stuck walking into them, forever. I can always tell when a party bus is arriving because I immediately start experiencing lag spikes. And nothing is more frustrating than when the game crashes, again, for seemingly no reason. I would also love the ability to add and remove items from the shelf without having to remove and replace the shelf, because once you put something on the shelf there's no way to take it off otherwise. The amount of times I've accidentally pressed "place all" is absurd lol.

I really do love this game. There's so much to do and I love to watch my gas station grow and manage my employees, and there's a large variety of things to do. But because of the prominence of bugs I'm forced to put the game down for a while. Might come back in a few months. I notice the devs are releasing DLC here soon and I've wish-listed it, but I'm hoping they crack down on the bugs, crashes, and glitches first before releasing them.
