There’s issues that can range from being from the last update or can easily go as far back as over a year ago, if not more.

(These are not in the order of importance.)
First issue is that some settings automatically revert themselves upon a game reboot/startup. I have to shut the “Car Horns’ option off every single time I load in, and yes, they can get pretty excessive at times. The options will even show that they are set to your desires but are still reverted.
Second issue, very random game crashes. It tends to be at low intensity moments, which of course seems weird. There are “guides” telling you how to lower the chance of crashes but I shouldn’t have to do the Macarena and pray on my tippy toes that the game won’t crash from something that hasn’t been resolved for over a year. This is a issue for a large amount of players, not dependent on your PC specs.
Third issue, the “Bus Party Events” cause horrendous lag spikes lasting as long as 45 seconds. Doesn’t sound horrible but it’s every time without fail. Yes, you can shut them off in the “Gameplay” section of the Options menu, which I suggest. I unhappily ran with them on because I needed as many customers as I could get for various achievements.
Fourth issue, achievements are random on when they decide to count to Steam. It’s like Stevie Wonder is sitting there with a “Yes” button and a “F*ck You” button, and he just slaps them like crazy not knowing what they do. There’s an achievement section in the game showing players that they received them but it’s not well communicated to Steam, thus resulting in the game saying you have it but Steam saying you don’t.
Fifth Issue, the “Late Game Challenges” are broken and very unbalanced. The challenges are great for helping with “Popularity” achievements but are about useless. Ol’ Stevie must’ve had a hand in these too… Some Challenges will just not track your progress whatsoever, others have such high demands with such a low of a time limit it ends up being impossible to do them at all.

There is probably more to say on the issues with the game but those five mentioned are the ones that really applied to me during my play-throughs. Do I expect every game to be a polished masterpiece? No. But seeing their efforts being put into DLCs, at least 3 new games, and not into long lasting issues in the base game causing some players to drop the game entirely, seems a bit off. Seems like they're putting their effort into DLCs/games that can get them more money and not attempting to resolve issues in the game that cause highly negative user experiences since that itself isn't profitable in the short term.
If you're wondering if you should buy this game, I'd suggest you wait for a sale or give it a healthy time frame so that maybe the issues are patched/fixed, if they ever feel to do so.

The simulation game Gas Station Simulator puts players in the position of a gas station manager. The purpose of the game is to manage the day-to-day operations of a gas station, including customer service, inventory management, and financial management. The visuals are simple yet effective, and the controls are intuitive. The simulation portion of the game is well-executed, providing a realistic depiction of gas station management. However, the game might grow monotonous after lengthy play due to the restricted number of possible activities and interactions. Despite this, Gas Station Simulator is a short-lived, amusing, and informal game. It may not be the most exciting or long-lasting game, but it is an excellent alternative for those seeking a simple and light simulation.

[b]January 2023 Update: They've made some optimization fixes, and the game now can run 120fps @1440 in most situations, minus a single event type, [spoiler]the party bus,[/spoiler] which can be turned off in game settings. They also seem to have added content to the game, allowing for further progression. My day disappeared yesterday while playing this game, I had a great time and was able to run the game for 9 hours before it crashed during the above said event. 
[/b]

Gameplay-wise: It's enjoyable. It is what it presents itself as - you operate a gas station in the desert and work to build it up to hire a staff and serve more customers. Over time you unlock additional side businesses to make money with - creating a variety of mini-games within the game. Within 10 - 15 hours, you're pretty likely to do everything there is to be done, so it's probably good to acknowledge that before purchase. 
[strike]Performance-wise: this is where this game fails. I can't explain what the issue is other than poor optimization(?). Running on a i7-12700, 32gb RAM, and a 3070ti. I've watched performance counters, nothing is being maxed (CPU & GPU show no more than 20% utilization). Starting a new game nearly crashes my pc, once it loads in the game is extremely sluggish and stuttering frames. This is when I'm trying to use med-high settings - and I'm getting barely getting 30-40fps. 

I do hope they keep trying to work on it and it improves, but in its current state, it's barely playable.[/strike]

Latest update after ~20 hrs: The game is fundamentally broken and buyers remorse is 100% with me. My saved game I started at the beginning will not load anymore. Prior saves that were automatic also don't load. 

The number of little bugs/crashes here and there quickly accumulate into frustration. Stuttering between menus, loading/unloading characters in and  out of the scene (the bus event), empty delivery trucks backed up as far as the eye can see. The game actually has a button to "fix traffic" which is nothing more than a clever way to cover up a huge bug they weren't able to fix that causes traffic to back up, cars and your excavator sitting on top of light poles for no reason, glitchy.  If there weren't so many bugs there's actually the appearance of a good simulator progression. The most frustrating thing is there are small minigames to complete activities that RELY on smooth performance to do them correctly. if you don't, your in-game rating suffers. That's VERY  annoying.

I continued to play after this review since I did pay for the game after all, which I regret. The stuttering performance in this game is so overwhelmingly frustrating, I'm done with this game. The dev team NEVER should've considered releasing any DLC until the core game works.

After paying off the final $5,000, the game froze so bad I'm not sure if I missed a cut scene that simply didn't load. Afterwards, a device appeared in my parking lot that just generates trash which doesn't make any sense at all. 

There are also numberous moments where there isn't a customer in sight and suddenly a challenge appears to serve 40 customers in your store within several minutes. I can't quite remember the amount of time but it's laughable. Days will pass without seeing anyone until you "reset traffic". Delivery trucks get stuck miles away for no reason. This game is awful.

7.5/10 - Never thought i'd enjoy a game where you are in charge of a gas station.
But here we are.
Graphics 7/10 - Ran this game on all ultra graphics (AMD Radeon 6600XT Mech 2x GPU) And it ran amazing and clean- Until the party bus arrives, then it goes from 51 FPS down to about 15 FPS. But other than that, I rate it a 7/10. Great style to the game.
Gameplay 7/10 - It gets repetitive after you get a handle on things. The incremental change with each upgrade makes it a bit tougher but it also makes it a little bit more boring once you get employees. However, It kept me busy for 14 hours. Between the stocking groceries and ordering gas, and then executing shifts between employees and maximizing profits through a changing price market I think it's one of the most entertaining Sims I've played recently. Plus the Garage is nice touch. It's like Car Mech. Simulator. 7/10
Story 6/10 - It's a fairly straight forward single player story. You play a guy who sold a car to buy a gas station. And Apparently, works for or with the mob. Not too many twists that throw the story off but nothing that sets you on edge. Just focus on your business. Simulators don't really NEED a big story-line to work with, But this one had more potential I feel. 6/10
Conclusion 7.5/10 - Gas Station Simulator DEFINITELY is worth a try if you enjoy Simulators that don't involve 3rd person top down view. It has a fair bit of Logistics involved. If you like to deviate from the story and run an absolute hole-in-the-wall station, or run a clean little desert jewel. You can do anything you want to your station and the future is completely in your hands. It's definitely for an audience of +10 years old and beyond, and it's a great game to get lost in for a little while. Might even be worth the 2nd playthrough.
7.5/10 Worth the $20. Thank you DRAGO for the game.

Thank you again "Let's Game It Out" Youtube channel. I never would've tried this otherwise. While I didn't play it like a goof, I enjoyed the 30 hour journey it took me to "complete the story." I still have a few more things I can do in the game (popularity levels). I will come back to mess around in it. I had a lot of fun, but I'll preface that I don't mind hopping in a "simulator" game to zone out and chill.

While this game can get hectic and has it's flaws, it was definitely worth picking up during a Steam sale.

Yes, the game has a good amount of jank to it. Yes, it crashes. No, it doesn't have a ton of progression depth. Yes, vehicles and customers get stuck pretty frequently. Attention: There are a few reset buttons around. Every in-game day or so when I had a lull in customers, I'd press the reset button. Not only does it fix stuck vehicles, it corrects a memory-leak issue that causes crashes. It was crashing frequently until I searched for this solution.

This game also has the quirkiness and charm of the "did we really need to simulate this" vibe like Barn Finders, but that presentation is far more polished and gets sillier. BF is "better" but GSS created more laughs in the jank dept. This concludes my TED Talk. If you'd like to read some gameplay mechanic spoilers and rant, continue reading.

Rant:

The register checkout minigame can be nightmarish to operate and I found myself avoiding it fully when I could hire more help. The item physics and incredibly small workspace made it annoying. You WILL accidentally knock something off the conveyor belt or into the basket before it can be scanned. I've never seen a customer get mad IRL when they got an item or two for free... it would have been nice if you could boost your popularity by purposefully giving items away for free to the detriment of monetary loss and no tip. Also, the NPC help is much, much quicker at completing each task with the trade-off of less money made. The math doesn't lie: it would take me about 3 seconds per item scanned. It's not uncommon to scan 10+ items. It would take me at least 30 seconds compared to the NPC's 10 seconds or less. They clear out crowds quickly and still make a good profit.

However, the hirelings are slower at cleaning and don't do car repairs well. Pathing issues, glitches, and doing the bare minimum repairs even at higher stats. I found myself putting NPCs on register, fueling, and cleaning duties (later, when I had more help).

Words of caution: DON'T move your shelves with product on them! The items can disappear and you'll lose what money you paid for the stock. This will likely come into play as you upgrade since you'll have more floor space to work with. So either let the shelves sell out, manually move EVERY item, or eat the cost. I've done all three.

Also I'm very grateful that the devs allow disabling of certain features. The car horns let you know if you have a delivery waiting, but OH MY GOD there is far too much honking. I couldn't be sure, but it seems like they honk at you if all spots are full or if there is a traffic jam too. It's quasi-useful early on as you get a feel for the layout, but of course you're not going to have everything opened up early on. Seriously folks, I'd estimate at least 1 honk per minute...

I also recommend disabling a few "events" once you've experienced them a few times. It doesn't hurt achievements. I turned off the holiday content and some detrimental features. The detrimental stuff is pretty frequent and I had a sandstorm, the graffiti brat, AND the party bus all arrive at the same time. After experiencing each event dozens of times, I realized they brought no fun anymore and only adds more monotonous play time. 

I also ended up turning off "warehouse theft" about halfway through bc I realized it was a time-sink feature. This game would have benefited from better progression. AKA, don't like having to manually unload the truck (NPC can't do this), how about an upgrade that unloads for you. The items could have had more depth and stats too, ie a way to track and stock popular items.

So, there it is. I enjoyed this game enough to write a review, but am surprised I had notes on improvements. That means I liked it enough I had feedback to make it better. If you buy, I hope you have fun with it too!

Circa 2008...
I'm still a kid, playing with whatever I can buy with various magazines in my local market or what is available on websites online. I'm enjoying all kinds of genres - racing, shooters, RPG, small platformers, or adventures, but the most fun I'm having is with small flash simulator games - carwash, mechanic, pizzeria, etc. I can play for hours but they still don't last for long, or I have to start a new game very often. I wished someone made any of those games into full AAA polished titles, with cool mechanics and amazing graphics.
Back then it didn't happen.

Today, in 2021.
I became tired of big games, with lovely graphics but too many half-baked mechanics. I'm stuck with my favorite online title, a few older RPGs, and one or two relaxing indie games. Most of the time I don't even play, sometimes watch someone else playing new titles to see if they will catch my eye.
On one afternoon Gas Station Simulator did just that. When I saw the constant struggle to clean up, handle clients, and somehow make a profit on a sandy piece of land I figured that maybe someone finally made my dream come true. I jumped into the game and was not disappointed!

This game is very honest about what it offers to the player. You are managing your gas station, there is barely any story to it (in my opinion there is no need for that). You're supposed to jump into the game and get pulled in into a whirl of duties. The graphics look pretty, all buildings and items look neat, humans... Let's say they look believable. There is enough customization with wall paintings, shelving, and decor. The sound design and music are nice, it reminds me of all those movies about Route 66 and deserts around California and Arizona. It gets a little bit monotonous but most of the time I don't actively listen to it so it's okay. Game mechanics are polished, fun, and just spot on. Probs to devs for actively fixing bugs and problems and for being self-aware - some bugs are turned into achievements! It's also great that they rather publish multiple small fixes instead of making players wait for a month for an enormous one. 
Gas Station Simulator also has some hiccups and problems. It's a rather short game, with a quite bad optimization and plenty of annoying glitches. They are not game-breaking but they can make you irritated during long sessions. Employee management is pretty bad, they are not always worth using for certain tasks. Rudy is slow as hell, which makes it unbearable to operate.

Overall I'm in love with the game. It brings me the joy of gaming I remember from my childhood and hopefully, it will bring me a few more hours of fun.

[h1]To put it simply: This game is pretty solid. [/h1]

[b]I've been bored and refunded on several simulator games. This game is staying in the library, if not simply because the time I'm planning to spend playing it would disqualify me from refunding it.[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
-Interesting, if not nostalgic mini-games that "Nintendo-Arcade-Minigames" lovers will enjoy thoroughly.
-Random event(s) that will shake up the hum-drum of the (few) grindy-ish parts of the game.
-Simple to grasp,  it's not intimidating to jump right in. (This game would be excellent for a new PC gamer, or for existing gamers who are trying to migrate a spouse or family member.)
-Lots, and lots of tutorials & information, of which you can return to at any point throughout the game.
-Realistic (I use this word liberally). It has a good repetition to it, with customers noticing if their favorite items are missing from your shelves. 

[b]Cons:[/b]

- Information for shelving content isn't available in-game, from what I could find. The game doesn't tell you an exact amount of items per shelf, but it matters! If you want to be able to 
calculate exact amounts for what you'll need to buy for your store's inventory, you'll have to utilize the wiki.
(I decided to use my real-life notepad and write down these values, which further suggests the need for such a feature in-game. Additionally, the wiki can be annoying to locate due to the Roblox-knockoff's success.)
-The paint DLC allows you to paint the buildings using a paint roller. This feature is fantastic in every way except one: once you click a wall to start painting, you cannot change the color or exit the process. The only way to 'move forward', so to speak, is to paint the wall whatever color you had selected, go back, and paint it again to your desired color. 
-This 'con' contains direct game spoilers. You have been warned. 
[spoiler]This con is more of a complaint than a real con, but it still counts because it affects gameplay, in my opinion;
The skidsteer/excavator has a turbo function that overheats the engine, which you then have to cool? I understand the need for a nerf to the skidsteer because the designed usage wouldn't take very long to finish up, but if the overheating feature was removed and the fuel was depleted a bit faster, the same goal would be accomplished. Besides being unnecessary to gameplay, it's just downright unrealistic. Real turbo diesel machinery is far more reliable than any other, and this is very well known about. [/spoiler]

In particular, having to constantly check inventory and order supplies and having to be present for any and all deliveries. The car wash part of it was just tedious and way too detail oriented for me. 

I honestly wouldn't recommend it.

If you want to be spared all of my text, I will just say that I would not recommend buying the game at full price (a better version of this disclaimer is at the bottom). To be more specific, try to buy the game and the Can Touch This DLC for around $10 - $15; if you are into the simulator games. 

For the good:
The game itself is alright. It's not awful, but it's also not amazing. I will say it feels less grindy with regards to money when compared to some other simulator games. I'm also positive you can't really lose money when buying and selling products. Meaning, you will always generate a profit since your cost of goods sold (inventory cost) should never exceed the sale price of that product; or, at least, I have never seen it exceed this value. As a result, the game seems pretty forgiving or not punishing; but, if you wanted to put more thought into your choices, you can still buy things that are on sale for a better margin. Some of the mini-games are decent (cashier, car repair).

For the bad:
Some of the achievements are just god awful to grind out. More specifically, the popularity level 9 and 10 are just insanity. For reference, I think a maxed out party spot event maybe fills 6 - 7% of the bar while going from 9 to 10. I've seen developers claiming that the spot should give around 500/600 popularity when maxed out. However, with the items and spot maxed out, I was gaining around 220 - 300 popularity per event. I can't fathom how they are able to get double the amount I'm getting when my upgrades are maxed; and the spot refuses to take more items (gives the text claiming the basket is full). Furthermore, it seems that employees can't generate popularity; but (maybe) can lose it. I don't really understand this choice; and the developers should really consider changing as it becomes quite tedious to try to do all jobs when trying to max out popularity. In my case, I tried to do the cashier and fueling job at the same time; which is fine. However, the popularity gain for the effort was just a joke. Please tune down these levels. Even level 8 can be rough; and the grind requires insane amounts of time even when doing tasks yourself, keeping things clean, and using the party spot.

While on topic of the party spot, we can talk about the Party Time DLC. There are probably other things added; but all I can recall is the party spot and ice cream stand. Given the above paragraph, I will talk about the latter. The ice cream stand just feels silly, in a bad way. The location is just terrible. You have people crossing one of the two main paths of your gas station to get to and back from the stand; which causes cars to stop and cause even more jams. This means that it may take longer for a customer to get in and out of your location; and that may mean profit loss from other areas of your gas station. Without doing extensive testing and research (which isn't worth it in my opinion), the small gains from the stand just don't seem worth it due to it's location. Furthermore, wouldn't other food choices make more sense? Haven't you made a game that has cooking in it with products like burgers? So, wouldn't those food make more sense at a gas station? Overall, with the DLC, it just feel like some sort of public relations ordeal. They give this "fix" for the insane amount of popularity needed while giving us a free DLC. I know what you're saying, but it's free. Sure, but half of it feels like a fix for an existing issue; which it doesn't even fix. And, the other half just leaves you wondering if it's even worth it. Doing the mini-game for the stand is fine and all for a couple of times; but after that, it's sort of just meh. 

Lastly, I would like to talk about the Can Touch This DLC. The price is small; which is good. However, some of the content feels like it really should've been included in the base game. For reference, the DLC allows you to double the base game's max  warehouse space, adds gas station floor space, and adds 50% more to the base game's max gas storage tank. The warehouse space feels like a necessity in the base game. There are plenty of times where I have had to split orders; which feels bad when I can just do one large order. I'm not going to dwell much on it; but I do believe everything that wasn't cosmetic should've been free. If people want to support the game, which it seems like those people exist, then just offer the cosmetic stuff as the DLC. Warehouse and gas station floor space is just extremely valuable; and it feels bad to have those things behind a pay wall (even if it's small). 

Finally (even though I said lastly earlier), there are some strange "fixes" that have occurred. From my experience, I would argue that the game is far less stable than when it came out. The game will just close randomly at non-consistent times. You can even tell the game is crashing because the FPS just randomly tanks in a weird pattern. It's like the game is trying to gasp for air. They claimed to have fix car pathing to prevent jams; but they still jam rather consistently and in ways that make you question your surroundings. Trash still goes through the floor. People get stuck on everything they can think of (Displays, outside decor that is placed by the developers, even the front door, etc.). Overall, I just don't know what happened to the stability. You get 60 FPS for the whole session; and then it just randomly tanks. I think sometimes the culprit is the party bus. Other times, I'm not sure. 

To summarize again, try to get the game on a discount. The concept and game loop are fine; but not amazing. There are painfully tedious achievements and questionable practices with the paid DLC. If you like simulator games, try to get the base game and the Can Touch This DLC for $15 or less. I don't think the game deserves full price.

Best wishes.

I've clocked over 100 hrs in Gas Station Simulator and I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by how much fun I had. The gameplay was smooth and intuitive, and I found myself really getting into the role of managing a busy gas station.

One of the things I really enjoyed about Gas Station Simulator was the variety of tasks you had to manage. From filling up cars to repairing cars to restocking shelves to checking out customers at the register, there was always something to do. The game did a great job of keeping things interesting and challenging, and I never felt like I was just going through the motions.

I also appreciated the attention to detail in the game. The various customers you encounter all have their own unique look, and the gas station itself is full of little touches that make it feel like a real place.

Overall, I highly recommend Gas Station Simulator to anyone looking for a fun and engaging management game. It's a great way to pass the time and really get into the mindset of running a gas station.

Not a bad game, I have to say. The otherwise mundane tasks of working the cash register, filling gas, and fixing cars gets very addicting at times. Sometimes I'll get into a groove of running around during a surge of customers and it feels nice. It is very buggy though. There have been times when cars have gotten stuck driving the wrong way or flipped upside down. My whole gas station can grind to a halt as one car gets stuck in an awkward position blocking everyone else from entering or leaving. I wish it were easier to fix than nuking the whole lot and removing ALL cars and customers because ONE person got stuck. When I saw that button I knew it probably had to be a band-aid fix for the cars always getting stuck and being impossible to individually fix. The party bus gets a bit annoying at times too. I always know they've arrived because my frame rate TANKS making the game nigh unplayable. I'll try to adjust my graphical settings to see if that helps. Carrying objects will have them falling through the floor or just not following you properly as you walk around with them. This happens often but not always. Dennis is pretty annoying as well. When he comes around I have to run to find something to throw at him, but after throwing once or twice, his hitbox would cause the item to rocket into space so I have to run and find something else. It may sound like I dislike the game, but I do very much like it. I just wish these bugs weren't so frequent! If it's on sale and you're into these types of games, I'd say to pick it up. Just don't expect the most polished of experiences.

This is likely the softest thumbs up I've ever given on Steam.

Overall I enjoyed this game. It took what would have been an otherwise boring and mundane chore and turned it into something fun and pleasant and rewarding. Every time you fill up a gas tank or every time you chase Dennis off feels successful. Random events and spontaneous humorous tones help drive along a narrative. Yet at the same time this game is endlessly stressful. Mind you, the point is likely to stress you out and keep you focused and constantly moving, yet certain aspects of the game really make you question how much fun you can have. For one, constant bugs and crashing is annoying in any game, but in such a fast-paced environment as this losing ANY progress is demoralizing. Further, environmental issues and upkeep despite your best intentions push you to the limit. For example, I HATE RUDY! I HATE THAT STUPID PIECE OF EQUIPTMENT! Never have I had a more uncomfortable and unenjoyable time as the time I wasted hauling around dirt with that thing. 

That is, until I discovered how annoying it is to paint. You have to paint ever section of the gas station, garage, and warehouse piece by bloody piece. Then the roof, then the poles and panels. It is so boring. And half the time my game crashes so I end up losing my progress. Additionally, many pieces (such as higher up walls and doors), the paint does not change color no matter how many times you coat it. Really ruins the purpose of painting to begin with. 

Another, I HATE REPAIRING THE CARS! It takes forever, barely pays out what you put into it, and constantly forces you to return to the garage whenever parts run out (which is every five minutes). Another, if you accidentally pick up a piece of merchandise from the shelf, it is IMPOSSIBLE to put it back. now you can only put it in the trash or leave it on the ground. Even worse if you pick up a car part which can run up to $90. at least with THAT you can use it if you don't lose it. 

Finally, I HAAATTTEE washing cars! I know I can turn the car wash off but it is the most degrading, unfun experience in the game. Combined with the fact you're unable to assign an employee to it, and my frames more than HALVE - it sucks. It's really bad. 

Overall, I reccomend the game despite its many, many shortcomings. As a final complaint, for the amount of time you acutally get out of it, this game should be $20 maximum. $30 is absurd. I spent $15 on sale, but again it costs too much. The 12 hours I dumped into this finished the game and now lets you go on endlessly, but I really can't take much more of it.

Yeah this is a decent management simulator. If you like management sims, you will get something out of this - but this is a pretty soft recommendation, because it has some incredible grind to it - and some pretty odd mechanics. Let's run through some of them.

Cash Register: In real life, if you accidentally drop an item into the basket without scanning it - you simply take it back out and scan. For whatever reason, this ruins your customers day.

Car washing: BRUTAL. Awful. If you have ever player powerwash sim, you will find this truly punishing. Your blaster sucks, you cannot upgrade to auto until end end game. Some cars refuse to be clean. And worst of all, you cannot assign your staff to this job. I closed my washer for most of the game.

Lock picking: Why? It is so out of place, I would rather not rob my customers. You don't have to do this of course, but why is it even in a mechanic. Very weird.

This is minor - but I don't appreciate being forced to carry rubbish. They go out of their way to make your rubbish bag look as disgusting as possible, but you can't empty your rubbish unless you fill the bag.

But most of all - this needs waaaay more automation to it.
Managing staff is pretty annoying, I would really like some sort of schedule implementation.
Let me assign staff to stock refilling.
Let me assign staff to order items when they get low.

I got 12 hours out of this, which is something. But it definitely is too much of a grind to 100% the various aesthetic updates.

I wouldn't say it's a bad game by any means. I just heavily underestimated the amount of chores the game requires you to do. Many people seem to enjoy picking up trash. I for one wish they'd streamline it a bit. Like for example they could give you the option to hire someone to clean up from the start. Right now you have to spend several minutes doing everything yourself. After realising when you unlock new parts of your gas station they are pre filled with yet more junk I decided to request a refund because that's just not what I got the game for. I also experienced random framerate drops even though my setup is more than plenty to handle the game on the highest settings. And lastly the controller support is really underwhelming. You basically still need a mouse for cerain things since gamepad input just doesn't work. But all in all I'd say my experience is very subjective and I realise I'm in the minority here. Just be prepared for chores.

Incredibly addicting management simulation. It has some 'House Flipper' vibes too in that you have to keep the place clean and you have the ability to redecorate and/or alter the walls. The bulk of the game is essentially managing inventories and employees as the station grows. The replayability remains to be seen but I am thoroughly enjoying it right now.

I enjoyed this game thoroughly, and I played it through to the end. I liked the customization features, the ability to physically manage an ever-growing full-service gas station, and to collect decorations that were larger than life (making my gas station look like a tourist stop). I even enjoyed the minigames. It was hard to put down. There were some bugs, but nothing game-breaking. And you can make it as challenging (or not) as you like by turning off/on certain features. Really fun game if you like management simulation.

All i can say about Gas Station Simulator is this: If you are interested in a simulator style of game and you only want to buy 1 game in the style, this is it. The addictive and entertaining gameplay loop of managing a progressively larger and larger gas station will keep you glued to your chair for hours. The customization and freedom the game offers when it comes to decorations and layout of said gas station is insanely deep. I will say that there is a slight performance issue that caused some frequent crashes when you start to get later in the story but, nothing a fresh install didn't solve.  In conclusion, this game is a master class in what simulator games should be and I am excited to see what Drago Entertainment has in store for the future.

The game is fun...when it works. Who would have thought someone would build a game about running a small gas station in the middle of nowhere would be a good idea? I'll give the devs credit for that, but this game has been broken for quite a while now the discussion pages are still filled with conversations regarding the same issues that have plagued the game for a long time. 

I still have ridiculous framerate issues, and with my setup there is absolutely no reason that should be the case with this game. Oh, and don't get me started on the constant crashes.

Like I said, if you can tolerate a game that doesn't want you to play it and will do what it can to keep you from playing it, this might be the game for you. Otherwise, spend your money on something else by a different developer.

29 Oct, 2021

I do recommend this game, but not at this moment in time. The achievement system is a total mess. I've counted 16 achievements so far which I should have received, but never did. There are occasional game crashes as well and random drops in frame rate. Overall the game content is amazing, but what is the use of having amazing content at the tips of your fingers, and not being able to enjoy it?

21 Oct, 2022 (UPDATE)

Almost a year later and some things have changed. Hardware-wise, I've gone from 750 Ti to Rx 6600 XT and i7-3700K to Ryzen 5600G. It feels like all they did was add more content to the game rather than focusing on optimization, because fps is still trash... YES, the crashes have been fixed, somewhat. When using normal mode instead of Dx11 Mode, It does still crash, however, Dx11 mode fixed that for me. Still getting employee chat screen-hanging bugs when talking to them and afterwards pressing "Esc" instead of the close option on screen. Now, for the fps issue. The real question is, do I have a shi**y system, or is your game made shi**y? Hear me out, God of War, Forza Horizon 5, GTA, Red dead 2... we can all agree, they look pretty good with the settings turned up. SO, to make my point, why can I run all of the above mentioned, above 120 fps at high settings, but in YOUR game I have to play at MEDIUM (Which looks terrible btw) and if I'm lucky, I get away with 60-70 fps, that is ofc if it's not lagging all the way to sub 50 fps... which is the case 90% of the time? It's not the end of the world, but it's almost the end of 2022 and high refresh monitors with variable refresh rates are become more affordable. Even with variable refresh rate switched on the game looks and feels laggy. I'll check back in another year, maybe by then they might have learned a thing or two about optimization and client satisfaction. Still, game has potential in the right hands...

If I had to say my opinion of this game in two words, it would be charming and addictive.

I don't write reviews often, but I just love this game so much. I saw Markiplier play it a while back and I decided to get it for myself and I was not disappointed. It has quickly become my comfort game. Since I began playing they have made some MAJOR improvements, and it has made the experience overall more enjoyable. Some of the more notable improvements are being able to turn on and off each individual station (the garage takes up so many resources it's nice to be able to shut it down for a while), the speed of the delivery truck, and being able to hire painters to paint the whole station.

The game naturally has the jank that most simulator games have, but it's done in a way that the perfect brand of charming shines through. Unfortunately, I don't think I would play more games like this simply because the experience would be extremely difficult to recreate. However, I will eat up whatever dlc comes for this game until the end of time. Keep up the good work devs!

10/10 i love running a gas station

Gas Station Simulator, a game where sitting still isn't really an option. Hope you enjoy repeated tasks and simple mini-games, because that's pretty much what you'll be doing.

Starting off with a worn down gas station, that needs cleaning, renovating, painting etc. To hiring employees to do all the work for you. Or well - most of the work, you can't truly automate your income here.

You need to keep track of stock, products, car parts, fuel. Earn enough money to buy new stock, as well as upgrades for your station.
There are events to keep you on your toes, like a nice young kid named Dennis who will annoy the heck out of you from time to time, ruin your freshly painted walls with graffiti, and you need to throw items at him, (Yeah don't ask), to make him leave. Not only that, but sandstorms can 'cause problems, as they bring piles of sand onto the road, which requires removing using an old excavator named Rudy.

I personally turned those features off in the options menu, which I'm glad you can, because they were just annoying to deal with, given everything else that needed to be done already.

Overall, I enjoyed this game from start to finish, but my ADHD brain helped with that, always needing to do something or another, preventing me from sitting still was rather therapeutic.

Wash car, check on store, are there still enough glasses and hats? Damn, almost sold out again, gotta buy new stock, wait, how about fuel? Alright fuel is good. Let me check the car parts in the workshop, Car wheel stand already empty??? Time to buy new ones as well. Employees need paid, fine, I'll do that in a minute. Hey John, can you handle the register real quick? Thanks, I gotta head to the warehouse to drop off the new supplies that just came in.

But that's all positive talk, but that doesn't mean this game is perfect, honestly, it's far from it. There are bugs, glitches, crashes that can absolutely ruin your experience. Certain aspects of the game are also rather awful. One of the biggest gripes I have, is that you can place shelves and decorations, anywhere in the store. However, the way you place said items is god awful. You can rotate them, but it's so scuffed that you'll never be able to place shelves snug against the wall, there's snapping for wall decorations and shelves, but anything on the floor, yeah no. AI also isn't great, both your employees as well as customer AI can be a pain to deal with, cars getting stuck, customers getting stuck, your employees not doing correctly what they're asked to do, or just stand there dumbfounded, forcing you to give them a task again, or move things out of the way so they stop walking into them. Thankfully it wasn't enough to stop me from playing, though again, it soured my experiences a bit.

In the end, I had fun, and might come back to start a new game, as I personally would give this game a 7.8 out of 10

The game integrates a lot of engaging tasks for you to juggle, but these tasks are rather literal and not gamified - man the cashier, sweep the floors, repair cars, etc.  You feel engaged but not entertained.  In addition, half of these mini-games are systems lifted directly from this studio's other games, which makes it feel less complete.  This is a simulator game where the micro-management never gets automated away; there is no upgraded point-of-sales system to automatically order new stock, there are no floor cleaners aside from staff.  I reached the end of the story before I quite realized I was getting there, because the gameplay loop was so low-level - I never felt like I reached the end of the tunnel to get to the good stuff, I was just in the tunnel the whole time.

The game has quite a few bugs, including soft locks and frequent random crashes.  They solve the soft locks by including a reset button that clears all cars and customers from your lot, which is like... yeah it works, but it's an obvious work-around.

The game is pretty poorly optimized, as well.  My computer is pretty well-fitted and I can't play this on the highest available settings, which is unusual for a game of this type.
The game gets a little boring after awhile but other than that it's pretty good.

It's a good game with amazing graphics where you get to run a gas station and repair shop. Love occasional dust storms. I have beaten all of the game contents which was  a bit of a bummer. I am mixed about recommending it, it has quite a few bugs still and since opening the car wash I have dealt with a ton of crashes. With some nice perks, like throwing things at Dennis the Little Menace, who would be in Juvie for vandalism lol.

Pros:
- The interface is good and easy to understand.
- You get to decide where you want shelves, which shelves, whether you want to add decorations.
- You can paint all the buildings and change the material of the gas station.
- You have the ability to choose what events you want to deal with.
- Can move cars with your broom. Love this.

Cons:
- The lighting is atrocious and lamps don't do much to increase it either. At least give us the option to buy more ceiling lights, please.
- The crashes. I had one in the beginning after launch then none for most of the game until the car wash. It may not be the car wash itself, it very well could be Gustvee causing the crash. Either way I cannot play more then ten minutes right now without my game crashing. It sucks because I haven't even done DLC yet.
- Disappearing items. Garbage is a big one that does this. I can pick up a bag and sometimes it'll either get stuck or vanish. But I have had that happen to stock items as well.
- Items that are set on magazines & newspapers, or too close to other items, that just fly off.

Overall though, I enjoy it. It has quite a bit of working parts and a little bit for everyone. Even though I hated working in a gas station, I do enjoy building one.

I wanted to like this so much, and for the most part, I do. Running a business is surprisingly fun and the creators snuck in a lot of funny gags (Dennis is great, the mob uncle storyline is kinda fun)

However, the constant crashes are a huge problem. Yes, the game autosaves, but not often enough, so I frequently lose progress. 

The game is really glitchy. Like Bethesda glitchy. There are workarounds, but it's annoying to have to reset my customers and traffic during a rush because some idiot got stuck on the lightpost trying to get out of the parking lot. 

Also, this game keeps you really busy until you're not. I was running around constantly during the first 20 hours just trying to keep the station afloat, and after I hit the 20 hour mark, I got bored. There are minigames to keep you busy, but I got bored of those quickly. 

I wish the cleaning/restoration part lasted longer. That's my favorite part of sim games and I felt like I got the station cleaned up way too soon. 

Idk, if you like simulators, buy it on sale, but don't expect a stable gameplay experience. If you're new to simulators, maybe skip this one and go get House Flipper or something.

It's a fun, but grindy game. You gotta put some time in to see improvement. Once you have employees, upgrades, and momentum going, it can be fun to get into a groove, and see your gas station grow. It's not gonna be for everyone, just like any simulator. Also it has some technical issues. Items drop half way through the floor, and you have to click on it more then once to pick it up again. Employees will just stop doing their assigned task, and stand there doing nothing, until you reassign them. Screen tearing is noticable, it personally doesn't bother me, but it is there. The game can be a bit janky, BUT it is fun. I work in a gas station in real life, and I wish it was this fun haha. I recommend it, but know what you are getting into first. That is any simulator though.

I cant quite describe why but this game is up there with my favorites. There is so much to love with Gas Station manager. All the mini games with pumping fuel or running the register are nice and easy. The customization is simple, would love to see more but I like what it offers. It be cool to able to put decorations inside your room above the warehouse, but you'll almost never be in there. I'd like to see stuff like a possible cafe added, mainly after playing Food Truck Sim. Either a built in cafe or at least shelves/stands for selling warm food like hot dogs, pizza, nachos, basic gas station food. Maybe even a soda fountain since most gas stations have those. My only complaint is really just with the car wash, I'd like the upgrade costs to be nuked a little. I can't really complain because the car wash is pretty much free money, nothing to stock or refill I mean, but 8,000 for just a level 4 upgrade seems high. Overall though, I absolutely love and adore this game for what it is and highly recommend to anyone, especially if business management is your thing or even if you just like simulation games.

P.S. I got the DLC and it answered some of what i talked about :)

Game still rough, buggy and feels incredibly cheap. Despite UnrealEngine4, game feels like it was made with old open source engine by a student. UI and control issues are still a big problem. Refiew Edit: the game description has been updated and now the gpu needed is up to a GTX 1070, i bought the game again and played for some hours, the new video settings im using (DX11 and almost everything high besides post processing, foliage and shadows and full HD, FPS stays above 55 and don't give major drops as before even when streamign the game) is  working very well with my pc config (i7-9gen, GTX 1050ti, 32gb ram), some minor bugs as before, and i'm editing this review right after the game did a CTD, besides a CTD, i can't find any major/game breaking bugs, for now i can recommend this game and i'm having lots of fun with it.

Old Review:  the game description says that is recommended a gtx 900 series for best graphics, my computer is a i7- 9 gen and have a 1050 TI GPU, and the game in medium preset, in Full HD (1080p, 100% texture rendering) don't go above 30-40fps, and often suffers lagspikes/freezings droping the fps to 30-25 out of nowhere, also sometimes it just go to 15-20fps without reason and stays liek that for something between 2 to 5 minutes, i played this game in the past, and it was WAY better before, don't know what the devs did, but they turned the game worse, is cool  that the game have new content, but the game is unplayable now so i can't even test and see the new content added...
i will change this review if the game goes better in the future, for now i will just refund it.

I liked the concept of building from the ground up to open a rundown store and make it successful so you can expand your business and improve it. 
Unfortunately I had bugs breaking the game on the 2nd time I loaded it up. I looked for what was going on, did a dev update break? Did Windows 11 or nVidia driver updates cause a massive rift in Gas Station Simulator? I could not figure out what happened between everything working normally as it was designed to do and then become unplayable the second time I booted the game. I did file integrity checks and nothing was wrong as far as that goes, there were no updates from anywhere from the time of installing the game to the next time I loaded it up. Maybe Dennis did it because I surely could not figure it out. 
I really want to try again with the major update and I don't want to be disappointed. I will recommend this game but I only got 2.2 hours before I had to uninstall it. It just was not playing nice, the belt broke on the register and would not stop so all the groceries were hitting the ground. I did not make any changes to key mapping so why that happened is beyond my comprehension.I painted the inside walls and start painting the outside and go to the warehouse to get a delivery. I come back right away and everything I put paint on reverted back to how it was before painting at all.
I don't know if anyone else experienced anything like this but I was highly confused as to what was going on. Maybe they fixed it with the new game engine and it might be worth another try.
So I recommend Gas Station Simulator for the concept which is unique and fresh. I can't recommend the version I was on before the major update only because I had broken game mechanics that made the game unplayable for me. YMMV but I've played lots of early access titles so I am aware of weird things happening. My machine is highly capable of running pretty much any game I play even if they are not optimized well.
 TLDR: I love the idea of GSS and want it to be a great experience, hoping the major update has fixed some issues. Buy it if you're adventurous and love a challenge because from the game play I've seen this title is going to keep you occupied for hours. I also wish listed the next titles, the Roadside Diner and The Motel sims so I really want this major update for GSS to be the fix I need to be able to play GSS without the game breaking bugs.

Gas Station Simulator is a game that lets you renovate, rebuild and upgrade an old gas station. You get to make orders, restock the shelves, handle the cash register, clean, refuel and many other parts that come with owning your own gas station. The game itself has been really addictive so far and I personally enjoyed it all. 

Pros:

• Let's you improve the property which gives you something to look forward to.
• The interface is simple and easy to understand.
• You can decorate however you please and put the shelves where you want.
• It keeps you on your feet but lets you close and open whenever you please.
• It lets you turn off certain events you don't wanna participate in.

Cons:

• I'm not sure if this is a common issue but it crashes A LOT for me.
• Grabbing certain items makes them either disappear or get stuck.
• Horn setting is available but it would be better if you could only keep important horns (reminders for the warehouse etc.)
• Employees should be able to restock from the warehouse by themselves.
• Lack of decorations and options to make it your own.
• No sprint.

There are a few things that I wish would be changed about the game to make it a lot better. The amount of sand being brought in after purchasing the roads, the lack of sprint and the horns but even with the Cons outweighing the Pros, I'm recommending this game. Just for the sheer fact that it's simple, addictive, let's you be somewhat creative and the price is not too much to ask for the hours you're going to spend in it. 

I think this would also be [b]REALLY FUN[/b] in multiplayer. Have your friends replace the NPC workers.

Edit: There is sprint now!

This game started off with a lot of potential, and it was very enjoyable from the off. However, after coming back to the game after a few updates, it seems the developers aren't so interested in smoothing out the game and removing bug fixes, but instead are focused on adding features which may bring them money in. 

A simple feature would be lining up shelves. You cannot/it is incredibly difficult to line up your product shelves neatly. This is one of many simple annoyances the game brings.

Had I written a review months back before I took a break, I would have definitely recommended this game. However, the developers don't want to tidy simple things up, despite the amount of time put into the updates. It's a shame.

This game is more fun than it has any right to be. These job simulator games are baffling to me but I really have come to enjoy them. You take on the role of a person who acquires a beat up, old gas station and you fix it up, paint it, run it, clean it and expand it. There's more things to do than I was expecting. 

This game does a really great job introducing more mechanics to you as you play and at a reasonable pace. Just as things started getting frantic, a new mechanic comes that eases the burden. I've run into a couple minor glitches, mostly with picking items up from the ground or moving through doorways with items. The game has a generous auto save that came in handy the one time I experienced a crash, I lost almost no time at all.

EDIT - the majority of the below seems to have been resolved. Still a few janky issues here and there, but it's a massive improvement over how it was.

Gas Station Simulator is enjoyable enough, however the amount of bugs is why I can't recommend it;

Trash falls through the floor when you pick it up
Cars get stuck easily (you can smack them with your broom and they have their own reset button)
Warehouse running out of shelving space despite having zero product in stock
Regular crashes
Some staff go on breaks seemingly whenever they feel like it

The fact that reset car & customer buttons exist in the world just shows that there are known issues in the game that were never fixed. I have emailed support about my other issues.

EDIT - completely forgot to mention the amount of achievements that don't unlock too.

So I will rip the band-aid off right away, this game is janky AF. It's ugly, buggy, and tedious. So why do I recommend it? Because it's fun as hell! The manic running back and forth between fueling cars, ringing up guests, fixing cars, washing cars, ordering products and supplies, it gets the blood going! 

As a fair warning, here's what's going to piss you off during the game:

- Dennis
- The sponge on the conveyor belt not working and the belt getting so grimy it doesn't move
- The highlight area in the repair mini games not working properly so you just end up removing the same bolt over and over
- The game stuttering and you drop an item into the basket at the conveyor belt without scanning it and losing your streak
- The ugliness (seriously, the character models are hideous)

If you like Sim games, pick this up, you'll have fun!

Its not often that I like a game with the word "Simulator" in its name, but this one I like, though it has a few flaws.

I played and reviewed the "Prologue: Early Days" version of this game before the full game came out a while ago. Dennis has come by many times and spray painted what look like giant flying hairy penis's (lmao) on my Gas station, so I was happy to see that they added the "Dennis Defense System" at the end of the game, which was funny and unexpected.

Some of the things they added are the Garage and Car Wash. If i'm being honest, the Car Wash really could've just been DLC, but I do like the fact that you don't have to pay for water. You do have to clean the thing out to get the water pressure back up, which requires you to go underground into the sewers and pick up these Trash Bags that somehow made their way into the water and feed said Trash Bags to this Alligator that for some reason is just chilling there. The Garage, aka the Workshop, I don't have any thing to say about.

I also like the bus full of dancing people wearing Alien and Dinosaur masks that stops by, I remember seeing my first one and just thinking "lmao what the hell!"

Not a bug, but I hate the Dust Storms. the game does start with a bunch of piles of sand that you have to get rid of using a tractor that eats fuel WAY to fast, but its kinda annoying when a Dust storm come by and puts a few down.

I was also surprised to see that you could pick the locks on the trunks of peoples cars, I remember when I saw the objective to pick 10 of them in 10 minutes for the first time, I didn't see it until I had like 3 minutes left and then panicked because I thought the Uncle was gonna come beat the shit out of me for not doing it on time, lol. "Hey Nephew, you didn't break the law by picking 10 locks on the car trunks in 10 minutes, *punches Nephew* give me all of your money, NOW!!!"

Their are some flaws that I hope get fixed:

1. The shelves that you buy can totally hold WAY more items than they do. The items on all shelves should be a little bit closer together, the Newspapers should stand upright like the bags of chips do, the Ice Cream things I think should hold a bit more, and the one that makes the least sense to me is that the bottom shelve on the Alcohol stand is completely unused, which I don't get.

2. The lag is super annoying and it only seems to happen when their are a lot of cars and people around, which is often.

3. I sometimes have to click on something like 15 times in order to get it to do something.

4. Sometimes the camera will just randomly look up at the sky or down at the ground or just turn around by itself for no reason. I doesn't constantly happen, and isn't really that annoying, but its really weird.

5. The cars will just glitch out for no reason, like I purchased a truck full of toys, which was like thousands of in game dollars, when it decided to fall through the ground. I know theirs a few red buttons to reset the cars and trucks, but its weird.

Those are all the flaws.

Their is DLC for this game, and at the time of typing this, there is only the "Can Touch This" DLC, which just adds a few more expansions to the Garage and Warehouse, some new tools and the ability to change the materials the walls are made of, whereas as normally you could only paint the walls. Its only $3 or less if you get the bundle, so its not a huge waste of money, but I could care less for it. They are currently working the the free "Party Time" DLC which hasn't come out yet.

Overall, I give this game 7 giant flying hairy penis's out of 10.

This is my stupidly long review.
If you like time and people management games, it's for you. If you want realism, nah.

It's supposed to set on Route 66, but having actually driven the length of Route 66, I can confidently say that it represents the worst, saddest part of Route 66. The fact is, this is the gas station that's gone under and fights for a second chance, as very commonly seen along the route. The many "Mom & Pop" businesses that collapsed due to big box stores.

You get a rundown gas station and with the help of your uncle, set to turn it into a thriving, fully-functional gas station.  First, he teaches you the importance of laying the foundation of your future enterprise, communicated through a payphone and email. Gradually, he gives you tips on refurbishing the buildings, buying inventory, opening to the public and managing the logistics. Since he fronted you the money, you'll inevitably have to pay him back...or else.

Throughout the reno, you can upgrade the windows, paint, arrange the shelving, add workshops, turn it into your very own Gas City, complete with minions. It's truly a test of how well you can manage people, time, and inventory of a moderately-paced business while dealing with the occasional disaster.

The bugs are very minor. My "issues" are gameplay and mechanics-based.
-The dialog and response system falls short and is often nonsensical. "That's just what I'm looking for" is a common response after you pump someone's gas. I don't understand that response placement. The next time that I'm in Oregon, I think I'll say that, just because.
-If you don't scan an item or it gets knocked off of the belt, the customer complains about you trying to cheat them. Maybe they're uber-honest and want every pretzel to be paid and accounted for. I can respect the honesty, but it doesn't make sense that you'd get a thumbs down for an object defying physics and launching another across the room. That's usually not your fault.

[spoiler]-There's a lockpicking mini-game that you need, once. Afterward, it's useful for stealing change. I spent "hours" picking locks because why not? I pick the police cars, I picked the cars being fueled, I pick the cars stuck behind other cars. People don't care about the money in their car, but they want to make sure they paid for that bag of cookies. I think it'd be more practical to have a "Press 'E' to open car door and steal money" option. Continued lockpicking doesn't gain skill, nor are there consequences if someone sees you. All-in-all, the picking portion is a waste of time when there's little to gain by doing it and you have a never-ending supply of picks. [/spoiler]

It's not all bad...
-I do appreciate that the employees are not super talented ultra beings, though. They make mistakes, like everyone else. ---The employees also drop customer items, they're slow, they refuse to service the second car in the repair bay, etc. Just like IRL.
-The animations during vehicle repair.
-Subtle nods to other games.
-Painting is oddly relaxing.
-I like logistic simulation, so there's that.

 My rational mind struggles with this game, but I still play it b/c in its ridiculousness, it's fun. I like stocking items, seeing 3 instances of Generic Cop at once and scolding him for buying alcohol while in uniform, [spoiler]getting kneecapped (off-screen) when I don't repay a loan in a timely manner,[/spoiler] and running around checking on the workers, filling in where I need to, etc. The game has a lot of directions it wants to go, but never fully reaches any of them. It's the alphabet soup of PC games. I can see that the devs are very responsive to the players, so I hope some of the loose-ends get tidied up, within time. While it's not AAA, it's still entertaining.
Love this game easily sunk 4 hours into it without even noticing. Only problem for me is theres no option to close the workshop please add an option for that. Other than that I love this game

A quirky little game, but also a lot of fun IMO. I got the demo years ago & bought the alpha when it was released. In the game you (SUPRISE!) own & operate a gas station. Initially you fuel cars & sell potato chips & candy from you're register, you're on your own & alone. Earn more than you spend & you can upgrade to a workshop where you can work on cars (garage here in america) & a car wash. You can hire employees to perform the more mundane tasks. My only critic would be the employee AI & the register mini game (advice hire someone ASAP to run the register). the game is quite grindy, but the Devs are still updating despite working on two other games/expansions. If you like busniess managment games this one's really fun

The only reason I'm not asking for a refund is because I hope one day this game could be playable. I'll just keep it in the shelf and once it's fixed as a game SHOULD BE, I'll as well fix this review.
For now, NOT WORTH YOUR TIME AND MONEY!

Edit: It seems the lack of controller support got worse along the way... I tried this game once again and it seems I can't even navigate through the settings in the main menu without using the mouse. I'm not sure if this happened before, but the fact that it hasn't been addressed tells you what you should expect here... I'll try again another time...

Very fun game with a lot to keep your mind busy. If you are running your entire gas station by yourself without the help of your employees there will always be something to do to the point where it is almost a little overwhelming. Even with the help of your employees there is enough to keep you busy.

If you enjoy this game and intend to keep playing it I highly recommend buying "Can Touch This," DLC for $2.99. Once your store gets bigger I feel your max size warehouse is simply to small when you have a store to fully stock and a workshop to fill up as well. The DLC gives two more warehouse expansions which in total doubles how much you can store in your warehouse. It feels a lot more comfortable having that extra warehouse space and the DLC has a lot of other features that easily makes it worth $2.99.

But the longest I've had this game open for just to get in my game (on the loading screen) was for about 13 hours I think. I left it open overnight, woke up, and it was still there. That's my only problem with this game personally that I just HATE. I can't even play this game unless I restart my save slot and just keep the game open on my pc forever.

TLDR: Mildly entertaining but CANNOT recommend in its current state.

Good = Active and responsive Dev team + some genuinely funny animal & NPC elements/interactions [spoiler] Dennis/party bus/sewer beast [/spoiler]

Bad = Poorly optimised, brain damaged AI, broken pathing, broken challenges, broken physics (can be fun for a laugh) + many many bugs
Ugly = Multiple reports of different crashing issues (Unreal errors, game won't launch, memory leak freezes, and more) with a noticeable uptick for Car Wash DLC users

Opinion = It's not a BAD game, but it's not especially GOOD either. Very meh. 
Most of the mini games/puzzles are copied from other games that just play better because they are focused. There IS stuff to do, but it's very shallow and repetitive, quickly devolving into push broom simulator.

I will revisit this review after the long promised patch and/or new DLC.

When I originally played the game it ran very well and I enjoyed it, I left for several months with plans to return to see what was added and how it would evolve. However when I returned, I found a broken and unplayable mess with extreme amounts of lag and moments where the game would freeze for almost 60 seconds. Restarting my PC, Running the game as administrator, deleting/re-installing the game, and updating all my drivers did not improve gameplay. And when I attempted to verify the game's files things got worse to where it won't even start. It just gives an error message saying that it could not be started. Deleting and re-installing the game does not even fix this. So now I am stuck with a completly dead game with no way to refund since it has been so long since I originally bought/played it. 

Honest reviews:
When I first got it: (7.5/10 solid)
In it's current bugged/unplayable state for me: (0/10 waste of 8 gigs)

They are good for your average sim game which is to say they are okay.

Gamplay
It is fun but if you don't like minigames this isn't the game for you, it can get very hectic with 5 different things to do at once. Thankfully later in the game you can hire employees to do what you don't want to do.

Audio
i mostly play while watching youtube but it sounds fine 

Audience 
pretty much anyone can play this game. Theme wise you probably want to stick to teens up

PC requirements
You don't need anything too insane the game runs fine but i do have a higher end system

Difficulty 
The minigames are fairly easy but it does require some attention. Economically you start off a bit strapped for cash, but as time goes on your typical economic snowball starts rolling 

Grind
The game does get progressivly more grindy requiring more tasks to rank up

Story
there is a story, but its not the reason you would play this game. I will say the 50s theme is really nice, except for when its broken by you having a computer. 

Game time
I am about 8 hours in and there is still many tasks  left to do. 

Price

Fun sim with a silly sense of humor. It finds a good medium between not being complex but detailed enough that it is still fun. 

While the name states "Gas Sim" there are plenty of other mini-games such as running your mechanic shop, car wash, property upkeep, product/part ordering, warehouse management, etc. Best part is if you don't like one of them you can hire someone else to do it.

It can be a little buggy, especially when interacting with objects, but, I've found nothing game breaking so far. 

Overall, simple, fun game with plenty of things to keep you occupied. Not sure why these customers at the check stand lose their shit when they get free items though.

In terms of Sim games, this one feels kinda bare bones. I really don't understand all of the outstanding recommendations for this game. It's about on par with most others. Just as buggy. Just as linear. Same simple gameplay loop as every other sim. Sell. Restock. Pay employees. Loop. It's high res and high quality. Obviously the devs put a lot of time into the looks. But it's just not enough to carry the game past 10-20 hours, which is a lot less than other sims in my opinion. It feels a little scammy considering the first 8 hours of gameplay are USUALLY the 1st-2nd stage of sims, which is the case with this one as well. However, the depth of upgrades basically ENDS after just the first 2 upgrades. After which the game devolves into a grind simulator. Sure, you get more room and extra shelves. But after you get the car wash, the gameplay loop is repeated endlessly. Nothing new is really added, which really sucks. There's not enough customization. enough depth, enough individuality to make it worth it's $20 price tag, when sims like Weed Shop 3 are far better and cost less.

Got this game during a 20% off sale. Honestly, even without the sale I'd say it's worth it. The game handles well, and has multiple job types to keep you from getting too bored. 

Good:
Job wise, you start with a normal gas pump. then you sell goods (like food and drink), then a mechanics shop where the parts you buy are expensive but the pay is great! You get also upgrade to get additional gas pumps, goods to sell, and thinks to change out on cars. There are more businesses to my knowledge, but I've yet to unlock them.

The game also features well designed building mechanics, resource and staff management, and building customisation.

Bad:
Only two issue I have, are that the RNG based product price system can be annoying, as I had to wait maybe an in-game week for a good price on tires, though once I did get a good deal I basically bought the entire stock. And I'm currently in a loop where I can't afford to get the third upgrade because I'm always buying resources. Though I'm sure with time and investing in cheap products I'll be out of that situation soon.

The game can be very grindy and time consuming, even if you are getting fairly consistent deals on products/parts. I just spent almost an entire day playing it, and I'll probably have to limit myself more, either by playing less in a day, or playing less days in a week.

Feedback:
I know "this game should have co-op" is probably a very over used, and generic statement/request. But I think it would fit really well for this game. Either make the host wait until they unlock employees, and you can have a friend take the employees spot. Or a special "co-owner mode" where both players own the business together, and the game essentially functions as it normally would, but co-op. Having one player focus on one side of the business and the other focus on a different side would be good fun and require decent teamwork as to not have one player screw over the other buying buying 40 tires. I can definitely think of a few friends who would be down for that if it existed.

Also, screw Denis! Little brat!

Edit: A couple months after my review because in case it alters anyone's views, I haven't returned to this game since posting my review a couple months ago. Do with that as you will.

This game has no right to be this much fun.

The core gameplay loop is extremely addictive, as there's always just one more task to complete, be it restocking your shelves, filling a few more tanks, painting some walls, or saving up money for that upgrade you've been wanting. The game's progression goes at an excellent pace, introducing new pieces of gameplay just as you start getting bored or frustrated with the current situation. While the amount of different mechanics might feel overwhelming at times, the game is actually really forgiving. Once you realise that, the game becomes a lot more relaxing.

I have some minor complaints, including painting being very tedious and occasionally annoying controls, but none of that really bothered me while enjoying the game.

As an offline simulation game, I loved it with all its bugs and crashes and I have two reasons for it:
Firstly, I love simulation games, but the reason I like this one is even though such games usually have a weak team behind them, this one was good.
Secondly, I love the atmosphere of the game since I usually don't find games with a similar environment. I love the fact that you are a lone wolf in the middle of the desert, far away from crowded cities, just serving some customers, and it feels like you are growing your sanctuary in the middle of nowhere from the wreckage, just to make a fancy shelter in the desert and from my point of view, this is a chilling and peaceful experience.
However, the game crashed hundreds of times during my personal experience in some situations and the game not only stops working but also gets force-stopped. As a fan of the game, I recommend that you don't pay attention to the Autosave mechanism and save the game manually and regularly until they fix the mentioned issues.
